headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Co.'s Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Results and Expectations for 2010. With us on today's call are Chris Connor, Chairman and CEO; Sean Hennessy, Senior Vice President of Finance and C
componenttext: Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Co.'s Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Results and Expectations for 2010. With us on today's call are Chris Connor, Chairman and CEO; Sean Hennessy, Senior Vice President of Finance and CFO; John Ault, Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President, Corporate Communications.This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Vcall via the Internet at www.sherwin.com. An archive replay of this webcast will be available at sherwin.com beginning approximately two hours after this conference call ends and will be available until Monday, February 15, 2010, at 5 p.m. Eastern Standard Time.This conference call will include certain forward-looking statements as defined under U.S. Federal Securities laws with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statements speak only as of the date on which such statement is made and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning. After the review of our fourth quarter and full year results and 2010 expectations, we will open this session to questions. I will now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. In order to allow more time for questions, we've provided balance sheet items and other statistical data on our website at sherwin.com under Investor Relations 2009 Year-End Press Release. Summarizing our overall company performance for
componenttext: Thank you, Jackie. In order to allow more time for questions, we've provided balance sheet items and other statistical data on our website at sherwin.com under Investor Relations 2009 Year-End Press Release. Summarizing our overall company performance for the fourth quarter and full year 2009, consolidated sales for the fourth quarter decreased 5.9% to $1.6 billion, due primarily to lower paint volume demand resulting from continued weak economic condition in the U.S. and abroad. For the full year, sales declined 11.1% to $7.09 billion. Sales from acquisition had no material effect on sales for the quarter or the year. Currency translation rate changes increased consolidated net sales 2% in the quarter and decreased consolidated net sales 1.3% in the year. Consolidated gross margin in the fourth quarter increased to 47.4% of sales from 46.2% in the fourth quarter of 2008. For the year, gross margin increased to 46% of sales from 43.8% in 2008. Selling, general and administrative expense in dollars decreased $14.8 million in the fourth quarter compared to fourth quarter last year, but increased as a percent of sales to 38.7% from 37.3% in the same quarter last year. For the full year 2009, SG&A expense decreased $108.8 million, but increased as a percent of sales to 35.7% from 33.1% in 2008. Tight expense management across all operating divisions could not fully offset the effect of the decline in sales on SG&A percentages for the quarter and the year.In the fourth quarter of 2009, asset impairment charges and a loss on dissolution of a foreign subsidiary reduced diluted net income per common share approximately $0.13 per share. Interest expense for the quarter decreased by $5.7 million to $9 million, due primarily to a reduction in short-term interest rate. Interest and net investment income was down approximately $1 million in the quarter at $580,000. For the year, interest expense decreased $25.7 million due to lower short-term borrowing rates and lower average borrowings.Interest in net investment income decreased $1.5 million in the year due to lower overall rates and lower average investment compared to 2008. Our effective income tax rate for the fourth quarter 2009 decreased to 19.5% from 36.6% in the fourth quarter of 2008, primarily due to the tax effect of the dissolution of a foreign subsidiary. For the year, our effective tax rate was 30% compared to 33.2% in 2008.Consolidated net income for the quarter increased by $15.1 million, or 30.1% to $65.3 million from $50.2 million in the fourth quarter of 2008. For the year, net income decreased $41.1 million, or 8.6%. Net income as a percent of sales increased to 4.1% in the fourth quarter this year from 3% in the fourth quarter last year. This increase was due primarily to year-over-year reduction in our fourth quarter effective tax rate and higher gross margin.  For the year, net income as a percent of sales improved to 6.1% in 2009 from 6% in 2008 largely for the same reason. Diluted net income per common share for fourth quarter 2009 was $0.58 per share, including the $0.13 per share impairment charge compared to $0.42 per share in fourth quarter 2008, which included an $0.18 per share impairment charge. For the year, diluted net income per common share decreased 5.5% to $3.78 from $4 per share in 2008. Now I'd like to review our performance by segment.Sales for our Paint Stores Group in fourth quarter 2009 decreased 11.4% to $920.2 million. For the year, net sales decreased 12.9% to $4.21 billion. For the quarter and year, decreased paint volume sales reflected weakness across most customer segments.Comparable store sales also decreased 11.4% in the quarter and 12.9% in the year. Regionally in the fourth quarter, our Southwestern division led all divisions followed by Eastern division, Midwestern division and Southeastern division. Sales by all four Paint Stores division declined in the fourth quarter and full year.Segment operating profit for the Paint Stores Group increased 5.9% to $119.9 million in the fourth quarter, due primarily to reduced SG&A expense and lower impairment charges that more than offset the decline in sales. For full year, Paint Stores Group operating profit decreased 7.4% to $600.2 million, due primarily to the effect of lower paint sales volume.Segment operating profit for the fourth quarter increased to 13% of sales from 10.9% last year. Profit margin for the full year 2009 increased to 14.3% from 13.4% in 2008. The increase in profit margin for the quarter and the year was due primarily to higher gross margin and lower SG&A and impairment charges.Turning now to the Consumer Group, fourth quarter external net sales decreased 2.2% to $240.1 million from $245.6 million in the fourth quarter last year. For the year, Consumer Group sales were down 3.7% to $1.23 billion from $1.27 billion in 2008. The sales declines were due primarily to weak end market demand most to the group's retail customers. Segment operating profit for the fourth quarter decreased $7.7 million, primarily due to the effect of lower sales and manufacturing volume partially offset by a reduction in impairment charges in the quarter. Segment operating profit for the year increased 12.2% to $157.4 million, due primarily to good expense control, reduced asset impairment charges and favorable freight and other distribution costs that were partially offset by lower fixed cost absorption from reduced manufacturing and distribution volume. As a percent of net sales, Consumer Group's operating profit in the fourth quarter decreased to 1.9% from 5% last year. For the year, operating margin improved to 12.8% from 11% in 2008.For our Global Finishes Group, net sales in the fourth quarter increased 5.5% to $437.1 million, primarily as a result of favorable currency translation. Sales for the year decreased 11.4% to $1.65 billion, due primarily to lower sales volume and unfavorable currency translation that were partially offset by acquisitions and selling price increases. Currency translation rate changes before acquisitions increased sales in U.S. dollars by 7.8% in the quarter and reduced sales in U.S. dollars by 4.8% in the year. Acquisition increased the group's sales in U.S. dollars by 7/10 of a percent in the quarter and 1.5% in the year.Global Finishes Group segment operating profit in the fourth quarter decreased $16.9 million to a loss of $1.1 million, due primarily to $25 million of asset impairment charges and a loss on dissolution of a foreign subsidiary. Segment operating profit for the full year decreased $87.2 million or 57.3% to $65 million, primarily as a result of reduced sales volume, impairment charges and the loss on dissolution of a foreign subsidiary that were partially offset by lower SG&A expenses.A fourth quarter pretax loss of $21.9 million resulted from the dissolution of a European subsidiary. This loss combined with asset impairment charges taken in the fourth quarter totaled $25 million for the quarter and the year. This compares with no impairment charges in the fourth quarter of 2008 and $800,000 for the full year 2008.Currency translation and acquisitions increased segment profit $3.9 million in the quarter and reduced segment profit $5.9 million for the year. As a percent of net sales, Global Finishes Group operating profit decreased to 3.9% for the year from 8.2% in '08.I'd now like to comment briefly on our balance sheet items. You'll find more balance sheet information on our website under sherwin.com, Investor Relations press releases. Our total debt on December 31, 2009, was $817.6 million including short-term borrowings of $22.7 million. The increase in long-term debt resulted from the issuance of $500 million in five-year bonds at 3.125%, the second lowest rate paid on five-year notes this year and the 14th lowest in history for an A-rated company. In January, we entered into a new three-year $500 million credit agreement to be used for general corporate purposes, including to finance working capital requirements and to support commercial paper borrowings. This agreement includes a provision to increase the size of the facility subject to the discretion of each lender to participate in such increase up to an aggregate amount of $750 million. The new credit agreement replaces Sherwin-Williams' $845 million five-year revolving credit facility which was scheduled to expire on July 20, 2010. Our cash balance at year-end 2009 was $69.3 million compared to $26.2 million in 2008. Capital expenditures were $27.8 million in the fourth quarter and $91.3 million for the year compared to $117.2 million for the year in 2008.Depreciation expense was $35.6 million in the quarter and $145.2 million for the year, and amortization expense was $6.9 million in the quarter and $25.7 million for the year. In 2010, we anticipate capital expenditures for the year will be in the range of $100 million to $115 million. Depreciation will be about $147 million and amortization would be about $26 million.I'll conclude this review with two brief comments on the status of our Lead Litigation. In California, the state Supreme Court will decide whether it is permissible for cities and counties to retain contingent fee counsel to aid them in their suit against former manufacturers of Lead Pigment. Briefing has been completed, oral arguments should not take place until at least the first quarter of 2010 and most likely not until the second quarter, with the decision most likely coming in late 2010.The Gaines case, a single plaintiff personal injury suit was tried to a jury in Jefferson County, Mississippi beginning in June of 2009. The jury returned a verdict in favor of the plaintiff and the company has filed a notice of appeal with the Mississippi Supreme Court as we believe a number of significant errors were committed during the trial. Briefing has not yet begun and a decision is not expected until late 2010 or early 2011. That concludes my review of our results for fourth quarter and full year 2009. So I'll turn the call over to Chris Connor, who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for 2010. Chris?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. It's hard to be satisfied with the past year when many of the metrics we use to measure our performance went backwards. The culture of our company is one of growth and continues improve
componenttext: Thanks, Bob and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. It's hard to be satisfied with the past year when many of the metrics we use to measure our performance went backwards. The culture of our company is one of growth and continues improvement and that doesn't change simply because the economy is faltering.If there is a silver lining to this dark cloud is that result show steady improvement over the course of 2009 and we ended on a relatively positive note in the fourth quarter. Our earnings per share, for example, in the first half of this year trailed first half of 2008 at $0.42 per share. Second half earnings, on the other hand, this year was $0.17 ahead of last year. I think this positive trend is a function of two noteworthy factors. First, the hard work of our people have done all year to manage expenses, improve margins, reduce working capital and minimize our effective tax rate. These efforts have made us a more efficient and profitable company. And second, the moderation in the rate of year-over-year sales declines we experienced in the second half and particularly the fourth quarter. Although, we don't believe our fourth quarter sales result signal a sustainable pick up in end market demand. They do suggest that some of the market segments are approaching bottom.Throughout the year, we made steady progress in streamlining our supply chain and managing gross margin and SG&A expense. These efforts combined with lower interest expense, lower effective tax rate, resulted in a 110 basis point improvement in fourth quarter net income as a percent of sales and a 10 basis point improvement in full year net income as a percent of sales. Our cash flow also increased as a percent of sales. For the year, we generated $859.2 million in net operating cash, slightly more than 12% of sales. This marks the fourth straight year of cash flow in excess of 10% of net sales. This strong cash flow performance was due in large part to a decrease in year-end working capital. Our working capital ratio improved to 10.7% of sales at year end from 11.2% at the end of 2008. This has two important ramifications. First, the decrease in working capital requirements increased net operating cash by $136 million. And secondly, Sean will have to stop insisting that 11% working capital ratio is optimal. Free cash flow for the year, which is operating cash minus capital expenditures and dividends increased more than $9 million to an all-time record high of $603 million as we appropriately paired back our capital expenditures.In the fourth quarter, we acquired 4.12 million shares of the company stock for Treasury, bringing our full year total to 9 million shares for an investment of $530 million. At year end, we have remaining authorization to acquire another 10.75 million shares. Over the past year, we've returned nearly $165 million in cash to shareholders through quarterly dividends. 2009 marked our 31st consecutive year of increased dividends per share, a string we intend to continue.This year at our February meeting at the Board of Directors, I'll recommend approval of a dividend payout rate for 2010 that will keep our record of consecutive annual dividend increases intact. I base this recommendation on our strong net operating cash performance and our commitment to returning cash to shareholders. In 2009, we continue to invest in our controlled distribution platform opening 53 stores to new markets because we believe new stores drive market penetration and share growth even in a down market. At the same time, we consolidated an additional 45 redundant locations for a net increase of eight new stores for the year. Our Paint Store count in the U.S., Canada and the Caribbean now stands at 3,354 locations compared to 3,346 a year ago. Our plan for 2010 calls for net new store openings in the range of 20 to 30 locations.Our Global Group continued to appropriately manage our automotive and OEM product finishes branches, opening 18 new locations and closing 20 for a net reduction of two. We ended the year with 539 branches in operation compared to 541 one year ago. Across all of our divisions in 2009, we've recruited 550 high-caliber people into our respected management training program and we invested more than $100 million in research, development and commercialization of new product technologies. We are confident these investments will benefit the company in the near term and deliver appropriate returns in the long term.Looking ahead to 2010, the steep decline in coatings demand appears to be moderating in some market segments in the U.S. and abroad and we are guardedly optimistic that will continue. However, there are still some end markets, most notably the commercial segments that are likely to continue to deteriorate in the better part of the coming year. Our exposure to these late cycle markets combined with the normal seasonal weakness in first quarter should result in our first quarter consolidated net sales being flat to down slightly compared to the first quarter of 2009. With sales of that level, we have estimated diluted net income per common share in the first quarter to be in the range of $0.30 to $0.40 per share compared to $0.32 per share earned in the first quarter of 2009. For the full year 2010, we expect net sales will increase in the low- to mid-single digits versus 2009. With annual sales of that level, we estimate diluted net income per common share for 2010 will be in the range of $4.05 to $4.45 per share compared to the $3.78 per share earned in 2009. Again, I'd like to thank all of you for joining us this morning and now the team will be happy to take your questions.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from P.J. Juvekar of Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from P.J. Juvekar of Citigroup.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You've said in the past that the contract of the business lags the DIY business in the recession and that has certainly been true in 2009. As you get into the recovery, do you expect these trends to converge in 2010 or maybe later?
componenttext: You've said in the past that the contract of the business lags the DIY business in the recession and that has certainly been true in 2009. As you get into the recovery, do you expect these trends to converge in 2010 or maybe later?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, P.J., obviously the contractors are much more affected by the new construction in the market both from a residential and non-residential and that's been a big lag on the stores business particularly. So obviously, as those new construction markets re
componenttext: Yes, P.J., obviously the contractors are much more affected by the new construction in the market both from a residential and non-residential and that's been a big lag on the stores business particularly. So obviously, as those new construction markets rebound and approach more normalized basis that should revert back to its normal process.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you think that will happen in 2010 or is it still going to be a slow process for contractors to come back?
componenttext: And do you think that will happen in 2010 or is it still going to be a slow process for contractors to come back?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the guidance that we're giving would indicate that some of it will start to come back. The residential market case in point most of the data points that we're seeing would indicate that the new residential starts should be up this year. The Reside
componenttext: I think the guidance that we're giving would indicate that some of it will start to come back. The residential market case in point most of the data points that we're seeing would indicate that the new residential starts should be up this year. The Residential Repaint market we think will continue to show some signs of life. That will be offset by the commercial market, which we have commented we think will be in for some tough [indiscernible] in 2010.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And Chris, can you comment on what's happening to sales trends in your stores in key states such as the key areas such as Southern California, Florida and Vegas?
componenttext: And Chris, can you comment on what's happening to sales trends in your stores in key states such as the key areas such as Southern California, Florida and Vegas?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think Bob gave some direction relative to performance of our regionals. Of note, the Southeastern part of the United States continues to lag the other divisions as it's more impacted by some of the new construction environments. That would be true of Ca
componenttext: I think Bob gave some direction relative to performance of our regionals. Of note, the Southeastern part of the United States continues to lag the other divisions as it's more impacted by some of the new construction environments. That would be true of California as well. And I think we're anxious to see as this year unfolds and predicted rebound in new housing starts should help those segments and that's included in the guidance we're giving for a better year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan Chase.

componenttextpreview: First question is your sales came in down six for the quarter and you were expecting down eight to 12? What parts of your business performs better than you expected to lead to that above forecast result?
componenttext: First question is your sales came in down six for the quarter and you were expecting down eight to 12? What parts of your business performs better than you expected to lead to that above forecast result?

componenttext: Jeff, really all three segments had a little better quarter than we had given guidance on. As indicated by little better volumes in each of those segments as well as sales for them as well. We also had a little bit of help from currency from our foreign operations.

componenttext: My first question is your full year revenue guidance is low- to mid-single digit levels and can you just give us a little bit more color by segment, primarily the Paint Stores and also Consumer? In particular to paint as to when shall we expect the timing for a meaningful top line growth?

componenttextpreview: Amy, the 2010 sales guidance incorporates positive sales growth in all three segments. So that would imply that all three segments are expected to grow in the low- to mid-single digits.
componenttext: Amy, the 2010 sales guidance incorporates positive sales growth in all three segments. So that would imply that all three segments are expected to grow in the low- to mid-single digits.

componenttext: But the growth for the Paint Stores should we -- shouldn't the growth of the Paint is to where channel should be, a little bit higher than a Consumer channel?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think that that's included in the guidance. We have commented that the commercial markets that we have a significant share over expected to struggle this year both from a new construction and maintenance standpoint. So time will tell whether
componenttext: Well, I don't think that that's included in the guidance. We have commented that the commercial markets that we have a significant share over expected to struggle this year both from a new construction and maintenance standpoint. So time will tell whether the stores business there had the second half rebound or not. We do expect that the residential markets will -- and that will help drive some of the positive guidance we're giving for stores but we do think we've got a headwind there, Amy, that's going to impact that.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And the second question is the volume trends across your Consumer group in the fourth quarter looked a little bit lighter than what your peer just reported last week. And then I'm wondering why is that and then have you seen any market share shift within
componenttext: And the second question is the volume trends across your Consumer group in the fourth quarter looked a little bit lighter than what your peer just reported last week. And then I'm wondering why is that and then have you seen any market share shift within the retail channel?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the Consumer group's sales performance is fairly indicative of how they've been performing throughout the year. There's always timing issues for that business as various retailers make inventory adjustments at the end of the quarter. We've looked
componenttext: I think the Consumer group's sales performance is fairly indicative of how they've been performing throughout the year. There's always timing issues for that business as various retailers make inventory adjustments at the end of the quarter. We've looked carefully at the architectural data on the federal government and other sources to get a sense of that Consumer group's performance this year. We think they've held their own, perhaps gained a little bit of share given the retail partners that they've done business with. And we would agree the quarter was a little softer than it might have been but no concerns there.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: My last question is really related to your pricing strategy across the paint stores. And obviously, since last summer you have adopted the route to the flexible [ph] strategy there. You decreased [ph], listed the prices and the stores for the DIY customer
componenttext: My last question is really related to your pricing strategy across the paint stores. And obviously, since last summer you have adopted the route to the flexible [ph] strategy there. You decreased [ph], listed the prices and the stores for the DIY customers? I'm wondering have you seen any benefit on the volume side from that strategy?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, I think we've commented briefly on this point. There were a number of entry-level products that were introduced to the store, a couple of rationalization of the lower half of our good, better, best finest strategy. No reduction in list prices for t
componenttext: Again, I think we've commented briefly on this point. There were a number of entry-level products that were introduced to the store, a couple of rationalization of the lower half of our good, better, best finest strategy. No reduction in list prices for the higher end products that we predominantly sell to that channel. So the impact of that has had very little to do both with volume or price erosion.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Back on Jeff's question , back on the first quarter, as he said [ph] the first quarter of '09, our asset [ph] expense was $42 million, $41 million. The prior year was $56 million. When you look at it we don't think it's going to be dramatically different
componenttext: Back on Jeff's question , back on the first quarter, as he said [ph] the first quarter of '09, our asset [ph] expense was $42 million, $41 million. The prior year was $56 million. When you look at it we don't think it's going to be dramatically different from the -- it'll be inside that range from the last two years, Jeff.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Sergey Vasnetsov of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Sergey Vasnetsov of Barclays Capital.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure if you already addressed the question of what's your pricing strategy for 2010? Typically early in the year, you make your business planning gesture [ph]. So can you talk about what you expect this year in light of slight volume recovery, sli
componenttext: I'm not sure if you already addressed the question of what's your pricing strategy for 2010? Typically early in the year, you make your business planning gesture [ph]. So can you talk about what you expect this year in light of slight volume recovery, slight pressure on raw materials?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sergey, I'd be happy to. Why don't I ask Bob to comment briefly on the raw material. In fact as we see it today and then, I'll be happy to comment on our pricing. Bob?
componenttext: Sure. Sergey, I'd be happy to. Why don't I ask Bob to comment briefly on the raw material. In fact as we see it today and then, I'll be happy to comment on our pricing. Bob?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Clearly over the year, we saw the upward pressure on the primary petrochemical inputs thorough oil and natural gas and the increase in those energy costs did have an adverse effect over the course of 2009 and early 2010 on latex. Latex is resins, so
componenttext: Sure. Clearly over the year, we saw the upward pressure on the primary petrochemical inputs thorough oil and natural gas and the increase in those energy costs did have an adverse effect over the course of 2009 and early 2010 on latex. Latex is resins, solvents, plastic pails, those types of petrochemical based products. Assuming the energy costs remained constant at current levels, we would expect that petrochemical based raw material to stabilize at or slightly above the current level. We are also seeing upward pressure on titanium dioxide largely driven by some capacity rationalization in the industry and we believe that some of the titanium dioxide price increases taken in the industry have been successfully implemented in the market. Overall, I think that it's difficult to forecast going forward because of volatility in energy prices and petrochemical products. But we believe the industry basket could be up in the mid-single digits for 2010. That's our best view at this point.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And Sergey, as you know we've been very open and transparent with the street regarding the company's pricing policies, practices and announcements. And as a quick reminder, our thoughts are here that first and foremost when faced with increasing raw mater
componenttext: And Sergey, as you know we've been very open and transparent with the street regarding the company's pricing policies, practices and announcements. And as a quick reminder, our thoughts are here that first and foremost when faced with increasing raw materials, we tend to push back on the suppliers. Secondarily, we look internally to see what kind of deficiencies we can generate in order to absorb those. And then finally, we take them to the market in the form of a price increase and I think our history has been one of -- following that strategy and with the courage and discipline to put pricing in when it needs to go in. We've also been very careful not to get out in front of our customers so we don't prospectively announce price increases over calls like this. It's only after we've communicated with our customers. At this point in time given the more petrochemical base or raw material increases, there had been some industrial coatings that have announced some pricing earlier in the year but the broader core architectural product lines there has been no pricing announcements made at this point in time.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America Corporation.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Kevin McCarthy of Bank of America Corporation.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if you can comment on macro assumptions, including existing home sales and starts that are embedded in your earnings guidance of $4.05 to $4.45 and whether your internal view is materially different from consensus of the economist out here
componenttext: I just wondered if you can comment on macro assumptions, including existing home sales and starts that are embedded in your earnings guidance of $4.05 to $4.45 and whether your internal view is materially different from consensus of the economist out here?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, we're not great economic forecasters but we rely on kind of the consensus of economist and there's a pretty broad range of assumptions out there right now for especially in the new construction markets. But we think what makes sense to us would be
componenttext: Kevin, we're not great economic forecasters but we rely on kind of the consensus of economist and there's a pretty broad range of assumptions out there right now for especially in the new construction markets. But we think what makes sense to us would be total residential starts and completions to be up in the mid-teen for full year 2010 and probably with growing momentum over the course of the year. So a lot of that that volume would be second half loaded. In the non-residential arena, the square footage decline that we experienced in 2009 for the industry within the mid-40% range. So we think that the rate of decline should moderate somewhat during 2010, but we think it's still likely to finish the year down mid- to high-teens in square footage. And we are late cycle on those projects, so we're probably still going to face pretty stiff headwinds in the non-residential arena. We think that existing home turnover perhaps will run perhaps not quite as strong as it did at the end of 2009 but we would expect it on a full year basis to be up over 2009 in terms of total transactions. We also would love to see the percentage of total transactions being foreclosure and distress sale related decline although that it's been pretty stubbornly in that 30% range, 30-plus percent range. So as we've indicated in the past, those kinds of transaction don't benefit us as immediately as an owner occupant selling to a new owner occupant. So we're rooting for the tax credit for both the first time-buyer and the step-up buyers to push volume early in the year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Just shifting gears, Chris, I was wondering if you could comment on your outlook for your international markets in 2010, and maybe comment on your strategic opportunities you see there looking out over the next few years?
componenttext: Just shifting gears, Chris, I was wondering if you could comment on your outlook for your international markets in 2010, and maybe comment on your strategic opportunities you see there looking out over the next few years?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as Bob commented early, the guidance for the year with sales revenues up in the low to mid-single digits would include pretty consistent performance across all segments, including that Global segment. We're seeing some improving economies in
componenttext: Yes, I think as Bob commented early, the guidance for the year with sales revenues up in the low to mid-single digits would include pretty consistent performance across all segments, including that Global segment. We're seeing some improving economies in the parts of the world that we generate revenue and particularly, Latin America. There's still economic strife in these areas relative to new construction and et cetera. But for the most part, we think they're going to be a contributor this year. In terms of opportunities going forward, we have been inquisitive outside of the United States the last couple of years. We've added a couple of strategic platforms. There's some opportunities out there that remain in -- time will tell whether we're able to get any of those in.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Don Carson of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Don Carson of UBS.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, if you put all your macro assumptions together, two things: One, what is your sort of final call on architectural shipments in the U.S. for 2009? And where would you see it going into 2010?
componenttext: Bob, if you put all your macro assumptions together, two things: One, what is your sort of final call on architectural shipments in the U.S. for 2009? And where would you see it going into 2010?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, 2009, through the first three quarters, the market in architectural was down in the mid-13% range, and it improved steadily over the course of the year. Third quarter was the strongest quarter that's been out so far. We haven't seen fourth quarter d
componenttext: Well, 2009, through the first three quarters, the market in architectural was down in the mid-13% range, and it improved steadily over the course of the year. Third quarter was the strongest quarter that's been out so far. We haven't seen fourth quarter data. Our expectation is that the rate of decline probably moderated a little more in the fourth quarter. We think that's a positive trend for 2010. And just based on all the inputs and particularly, what we would assume to be a better vitality in the repaint markets, we would expect our architectural shipments to be up in 2010.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So you think it was, what, down maybe 10% at the end of the day for full year 2009?
componenttext: So you think it was, what, down maybe 10% at the end of the day for full year 2009?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Probably more than that. That fourth quarter is a small quarter, so we were down 13.5% [indiscernible] Q3.
componenttext: Probably more than that. That fourth quarter is a small quarter, so we were down 13.5% [indiscernible] Q3.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And so maybe a slight, what, mid-single digit bounce in 2010?
componenttext: And so maybe a slight, what, mid-single digit bounce in 2010?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's reasonable, low to mid.
componenttext: I think that's reasonable, low to mid.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then a question on the Consumer Group in the manufacturing side, did you take significant fixed cost absorption in the fourth quarter? Is that why the results were so low? And I know in 2009 you were very cautious in building inventories for the paint
componenttext: And then a question on the Consumer Group in the manufacturing side, did you take significant fixed cost absorption in the fourth quarter? Is that why the results were so low? And I know in 2009 you were very cautious in building inventories for the paint season, are you showing similar caution this year?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think when you see the way our inventory dropped in the fourth quarter, yes, you're absolutely right. If you take a look at the absorption that we had in the fourth quarter, it did negatively affect how Consumer segment to reporting of the income. On th
componenttext: I think when you see the way our inventory dropped in the fourth quarter, yes, you're absolutely right. If you take a look at the absorption that we had in the fourth quarter, it did negatively affect how Consumer segment to reporting of the income. On the flip side, I would tell you that with the inventory at this level, we feel that the inventory build should be -- look very normal as it has for prior to two years ago. So I think you'll see our inventory build in the first quarter for the season.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Eric Bosshard of Cleveland Research Company.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Eric Bosshard of Cleveland Research Company.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, on gross margin, I think you commented that the input basket you expected for the industry to be up kind of mid-single digits in 2010. Where did that end up do you think in 2009?
componenttext: First of all, on gross margin, I think you commented that the input basket you expected for the industry to be up kind of mid-single digits in 2010. Where did that end up do you think in 2009?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It was down slightly in '09. So that's interest for the industry, probably down slightly in '09.
componenttext: It was down slightly in '09. So that's interest for the industry, probably down slightly in '09.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then tied onto that, what is the gross margin expanded? I think the maybe an all-time peak in 2009 punctuated by the fourth quarter, which has got to be an all-time peak for the business, but what is the expectation for gross margin in 2010, with inpu
componenttext: And then tied onto that, what is the gross margin expanded? I think the maybe an all-time peak in 2009 punctuated by the fourth quarter, which has got to be an all-time peak for the business, but what is the expectation for gross margin in 2010, with input cost for the industry up in this mid-single digit range?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. You're absolutely right, Eric. The gross margin in the fourth quarter, as well as the year, is our all-time peak. When we take a look at our guidance for next year, we're really aren't going to go down the list of SG&A or margin at this time, we're j
componenttext: Yes. You're absolutely right, Eric. The gross margin in the fourth quarter, as well as the year, is our all-time peak. When we take a look at our guidance for next year, we're really aren't going to go down the list of SG&A or margin at this time, we're just not prepared to go through each and every line of the P&L for our guidance. As the year comes in clearer, as we get through a quarter or two, this has been our practice, I think, the last couple of years, at the end of the second quarter, we give some kind of guidance for the year for the margins. So I think that's when you'll see us give a little more guidance on the margin for the year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I just -- when I heard that inputs were up five and pricing, I think, you indicated early in the call for the year you thought maybe flat to up slightly, is there some other opportunity to argument gross margin in light of what those appear to be
componenttext: I guess I just -- when I heard that inputs were up five and pricing, I think, you indicated early in the call for the year you thought maybe flat to up slightly, is there some other opportunity to argument gross margin in light of what those appear to be headwind?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to be careful about the pricing comments. I don't think we gave a comment that it'll be up flat or up slightly. I mean, we commented that on the industrial products we have taken some pricing out, and we've not made any announcements on architectur
componenttext: I want to be careful about the pricing comments. I don't think we gave a comment that it'll be up flat or up slightly. I mean, we commented that on the industrial products we have taken some pricing out, and we've not made any announcements on architectural at this point in time. And to your second part of the question, there's all kinds of levers that the company has at its disposal to try to work on that. Don't forget that last year was an aggressive rightsizing time for the company, a number of manufacturing facilities were permanently closed and disposed of and gallons have move to more efficient facilities that'll potentially have a positive impact on margins as well. So I think Sean's got the right approach here. Let's see how this year starts to unfold. We'll give more color on that in the second quarter call. And given our history, Eric, and the importance we place on margins, I think you're going to expect we'll be playing close attention to that number as the year begins.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question I wanted to ask related to margin. I think, Sean, you commented coming out of 3Q that 90% of the SG&A hit that point was fixed, then you had taken a lot of SG&A out. And I know you did some things in the organization 2009 to t
componenttext: And then the second question I wanted to ask related to margin. I think, Sean, you commented coming out of 3Q that 90% of the SG&A hit that point was fixed, then you had taken a lot of SG&A out. And I know you did some things in the organization 2009 to tighten down on SG&A, in light of the revenue pressure you saw. I should look at the year where revenues are going to grow in 2010. And I know again, Sean, you don't want to go on the income statement but should we expect -- how should we think about SG&A and how do you think strategically about the need to invest back in SG&A as the industry starts to grow again?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what happens is -- you're absolutely right. Clearly, we started early in 2008 to very [ph] attack or rightsizing of that the company. And you saw that our SG&A was down close to $110 million, down $52 million, in the first half of the year, 1
componenttext: Yes, I think what happens is -- you're absolutely right. Clearly, we started early in 2008 to very [ph] attack or rightsizing of that the company. And you saw that our SG&A was down close to $110 million, down $52 million, in the first half of the year, 14. And that's really what my 90% comment is, is we've been anniversarying these cuts and these changes that we've made over the last, really, two years. And we're at the point where we've anniversaried a great deal of them. I will tell you that if the volume comes back, we think our margins --we'll still have really nice room for margin and expansion, just like we did between 2002 and 2007. But when you take a look at the SG&A, they'll grow because as we bring people back to make sure that we have good customer service for our customers, we will increase the SG&A as the volume increases.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then the last question was the revenue on the first quarter guided flat to slightly down, and the full year revenue guidance implies that kind of material improvement 2Q to 4Q. And I know those were the big recorders, in 1Q it's less important. But co
componenttext: And then the last question was the revenue on the first quarter guided flat to slightly down, and the full year revenue guidance implies that kind of material improvement 2Q to 4Q. And I know those were the big recorders, in 1Q it's less important. But could you just talk a little bit about the visibility or confidence that you have on the incremental revenue performance in 2Q to 4Q relative to 1Q?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that some of the things that we're commenting on and that we expect to be slightly better in the year are, Eric, including new residential construction and turnover. We're seeing permit activity as we meet with our largest homebuilder custome
componenttext: Yes, I think that some of the things that we're commenting on and that we expect to be slightly better in the year are, Eric, including new residential construction and turnover. We're seeing permit activity as we meet with our largest homebuilder customers and get a sense of their plans for the year and their confidence. Those things are all pointing to a positive lift in that part of the business. Bob's commented a little bit on the resale activity and what we think is likely to happen there as well, too. So we think that this will be a year where we'll start to come off the bottom in some of these segments and that supports the guidance we've provided.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Ivy Zelman of Zelman and Associates.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Ivy Zelman of Zelman and Associates.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: But with respect to understanding the levers going forward, I think you've outlined where you're concerned on commercial real estate. One of the things that you've talked a little bit about in the past is sort of understanding, Chris, what CapEx dollars y
componenttext: But with respect to understanding the levers going forward, I think you've outlined where you're concerned on commercial real estate. One of the things that you've talked a little bit about in the past is sort of understanding, Chris, what CapEx dollars your customers or those that are spending today. Have you seen any change in willingness to go above the bare minimum? And is it possible that there could be some surprises, maybe where the guidance you would say is marginally too conservative, if you have -- looking at the levers?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well that's a lot of perspective thinking. Let me just share with you the way we think about that. Clearly this year, as reports have come out, we have seen the CapEx numbers for many of these commercial-type applications cut back just as we have at our c
componenttext: Well that's a lot of perspective thinking. Let me just share with you the way we think about that. Clearly this year, as reports have come out, we have seen the CapEx numbers for many of these commercial-type applications cut back just as we have at our company. It does have an impact on maintenance. If companies have done a nice job with cash across the United States, so to the expect that they would feel a little better about getting back on some of the CapEx spending for next year, that's a possibility. We're more focused, however, on the fact that these assets do need to be maintained over time. And failure to coat corrosive environment to protect steel and concrete, eventually ends up being a much bigger ticket than repairing with paint. And so we are aware that many of these projects and customers have extended already what a normal repaint cycle will be. This is very consistent to the 2001, 2002 time period, where this business segment went through a similar process. There maybe a little more of a tail to it yet, Ivy, but at some point in time, we think this'll come back. And I think it's back to Eric's point about the second half guidance is a little stronger than the first half, that should start to play a role then.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Just quickly on these, I guess, opportunities, we've asked this before but foreclosures, lots of investors buying them and yet, you have yet to see a benefit. Certainly you'd expect the paint would be a product that they would use to try to get them salea
componenttext: Just quickly on these, I guess, opportunities, we've asked this before but foreclosures, lots of investors buying them and yet, you have yet to see a benefit. Certainly you'd expect the paint would be a product that they would use to try to get them saleable or rentable. Anything that you can help us understand if that's a trend that's going to benefit you that you're seeing yet?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Ivy, I think, eventually, yes. I think that the investors that are buying those homes are certainly not doing so with the anticipation of being landlords long term. When the markets recover, when we start seeing home values move back up, I believe they're
componenttext: Ivy, I think, eventually, yes. I think that the investors that are buying those homes are certainly not doing so with the anticipation of being landlords long term. When the markets recover, when we start seeing home values move back up, I believe they're going to -- a large percentage of them are going to flip those properties for profit. And at that point in time, when they're really investing in premium upgrades for the properties, we should see a benefit. In the meantime, in many of these markets, they are parking these homes on the rental market and putting minimal cash investment in them. And a lot of the pros that are working on these properties are not only doing paint work and maintenance work but they're replacing floor covering and doing minimal electrical and plumbing upgrades or bringing them up to the code in those regards, and maybe a little landscaping. And these are primarily remodelers and handymen that are buying their supplies at one-stop outlet. And we think that some of this relative strength we've seen behind the home centers has been a reflection of that type of investment in these foreclosed properties.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Saul Ludwig of KeyBanc.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The foreign subsidiary that you dissolved, let's talk a little more about what that was and did that entity have an operating loss in 2009 that goes away in 2010?
componenttext: The foreign subsidiary that you dissolved, let's talk a little more about what that was and did that entity have an operating loss in 2009 that goes away in 2010?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me cover the business side of it and let Sean comment a little bit on the second part of your question. So this was an automotive aftermarket company that was operating in Italy. And as we commented on the call, we have dissolved that business unit. T
componenttext: Let me cover the business side of it and let Sean comment a little bit on the second part of your question. So this was an automotive aftermarket company that was operating in Italy. And as we commented on the call, we have dissolved that business unit. There are segments of that business that we'll continue to hang onto and service through other assets that we have in the region.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And when you take a look at the operations, Saul, it did have an operating loss but it's not material. When we take a look at what's going to happen, we will have some improvement there next year but not as great as the write-off because of the amount tha
componenttext: And when you take a look at the operations, Saul, it did have an operating loss but it's not material. When we take a look at what's going to happen, we will have some improvement there next year but not as great as the write-off because of the amount that we have on our balance sheet.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Then this impairment of trademarks and goodwill seems to be a recurring thing each year, is some additional write-offs baked into your guidance?
componenttext: Then this impairment of trademarks and goodwill seems to be a recurring thing each year, is some additional write-offs baked into your guidance?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Saul, when we take a look at our guidance each and every year, what really these impairments are as it relates to, take, different assets, you're evaluating your balance sheet. You're making sure your balance sheet is stated correctly. And w
componenttext: Yes, I think, Saul, when we take a look at our guidance each and every year, what really these impairments are as it relates to, take, different assets, you're evaluating your balance sheet. You're making sure your balance sheet is stated correctly. And when you are doing acquisitions and you're putting goodwill on there, impairments the only way to take some of the goodwill off your balance sheet, the amortization has gone away. So in each and every year, we have some room in our guidance between the $4.05 and the $4.45 for some impairments.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: What was the decrease in SG&A in the fourth quarter? What decrease in SG&A in the three segments, if you provide that in your 10-K reported branch [ph].

componenttext: Yes, in the Storage Group -- just give me 10 seconds to figure out. In the admin, SG&A was down 17. And the Global, our SG&A was actually up two. SG&A was up eight in Consumer and then in Storage Group, it was down 17.

componenttextpreview: I think we're going to be relatively flat. And I think that when you take a look at the cash separation, I think at the end of 2010, right now we're going to be in that $800 million to $850 million range. With a cash generation, we're going, as Bob commen
componenttext: I think we're going to be relatively flat. And I think that when you take a look at the cash separation, I think at the end of 2010, right now we're going to be in that $800 million to $850 million range. With a cash generation, we're going, as Bob commented, CapEx we believe we have to be $100 million to $115 million. We think that the dividend will be approximately $160 million, and we don't think that will change. We'll have acquisitions and we'll also do some stock buybacks if there is no acquisition.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess we assume [ph] or we're looking at the full funds [ph] that given the $850 million cash from operations and then subtract the dividend and the cash spending, that you're going to keep your cash in this, call it, $50 million range, and that flat ki
componenttext: I guess we assume [ph] or we're looking at the full funds [ph] that given the $850 million cash from operations and then subtract the dividend and the cash spending, that you're going to keep your cash in this, call it, $50 million range, and that flat kind of the delta will be what's available for share buyback and acquisitions.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from John Roberts of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from John Roberts of Buckingham Research.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: What's the store's outlook for 2010 in terms of new stores? And do you have any statistics on total industry stores? I assume total industry must be down in terms of store count.
componenttext: What's the store's outlook for 2010 in terms of new stores? And do you have any statistics on total industry stores? I assume total industry must be down in terms of store count.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our store count expectations, John, for next year, would be a net increase of around 20 to 30 in that Canada, U.S., Caribbean group that the stores is responsible for that geography. That'll be made up of fewer store closings than we've experienced t
componenttext: Yes. Our store count expectations, John, for next year, would be a net increase of around 20 to 30 in that Canada, U.S., Caribbean group that the stores is responsible for that geography. That'll be made up of fewer store closings than we've experienced the last couple of years. We're nearing the end of this redundant process we've been on to try to get out some of the recent acquisitions that are in a very, very close proximity to existing Sherwin stores. So we're slowing down just the gross new store openings, far fewer closings and that'll bring us in at that 20, 30 net. Our sense is that they're somewhere in the neighborhood of around 50,000-plus locations that sell paint in the United States. And that the independent company-owned paint store channel were somewhere between 10,000 and 12,000 locations prior to the downturn that we've gone through the last year and a half. Don't have good numbers on that, at this point in time, to share with you, but I think your expectations are probably accurate. We've seen quite a number of them, primarily the smaller, what we would call the mom and pops, struggle to make it through. We've always said that 4,000 stores is our next kind of mile market. We think the geography clearly supports that. And that won't be a net addition, but rather a number of these other facilities will have to go out to keep that kind of 10,000 to 12,000 location constant. So, don't have a hard number for you but I think your logic is right on track.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Yes. One of the things about the cash, because of our tax rate -- our tax rate came in at 30% for the year. Without this dissolution then it would've been 31.5%. So we did get some tax goodness, and when you take a look at the cash, it was almost cash positive for us.

componenttext: Can you comment on within this speakers [ph] national operations, Chris, in 2009, how Brazil performed and what you might be willing to say about 2010?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brazil was the star of our international operations in 2008, went through a similar economic slowdown in '09, characterized by significant slowdowns in commercial and new construction and maintenance of existing property. So it's been a little bit of
componenttext: Yes, Brazil was the star of our international operations in 2008, went through a similar economic slowdown in '09, characterized by significant slowdowns in commercial and new construction and maintenance of existing property. So it's been a little bit of a swing for us in that part of the world. 2010, as we sit here now, looks like it's going to be an okay year for us. It's included in that guidance that we gave that our Global Group would be up in that low to mid-single digit range. Brazil is our largest country outside of the North American countries. So that plays a big role on that guidance.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then a comment on what you think your paint store did in terms of market share growth in a tough year last year and a declining market?
componenttext: And then a comment on what you think your paint store did in terms of market share growth in a tough year last year and a declining market?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the short answer is that we probably lost a little bit of share, mostly related to the fact that there was a significant shift from the contractor towards the DIY as we saw in full [ph] throughout the year. More importantly, as we measure the shar
componenttext: I think the short answer is that we probably lost a little bit of share, mostly related to the fact that there was a significant shift from the contractor towards the DIY as we saw in full [ph] throughout the year. More importantly, as we measure the share performance against very specific segments and as you know, we break the contractor segments out into new residential construction and residential repaint and property management. And I would say pretty much across the board, Chuck, our confidence is fairly high that we gain share in each of those segments. But given the fact that those segments were down 35%, 40%, to the industry being down in the 13% range that Bob commented on, that's a tough battle to hold yourself into and gain share overall. A little bit of a share loss against the total industry, strengthening of share against the key segments and when they rebound, we think the company will come back fine.

componenttext: Right, Jay, I don't have a clue. I think there will be a fair amount of pressure on the administration, on Congress to extend them, whether they will move in that direction or not, we don't know. We do expect that either way, there will be a similar effect as we saw in late '09. And that is you're going to see a lot of transactions bunched up in March and April for closing. And then if they do extend that you're probably going to see a dearth of transactions follow that because they'll say we've got more time and we're going to take our time, kind of like you saw in November, December.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Just kind of to get a little bit better understanding on the raw material environment, are the Latin American raw material costs basically moving in line with North America? Or is there some sort of lag, I mean, as we look for these costs to start turning
componenttext: Just kind of to get a little bit better understanding on the raw material environment, are the Latin American raw material costs basically moving in line with North America? Or is there some sort of lag, I mean, as we look for these costs to start turning around in the U.S.? Can we make assumptions that same thing is happening in Latin America?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we're seeing is globally, they're moving in -- not lockstep but in the same directionally. The interesting thing about on the Global side, what will happen is especially when currencies are getting stronger, a lot of times what will happen in th
componenttext: Yes, what we're seeing is globally, they're moving in -- not lockstep but in the same directionally. The interesting thing about on the Global side, what will happen is especially when currencies are getting stronger, a lot of times what will happen in the local currency, a lot of these raw materials are being priced in the U.S. dollar. So as the U.S. dollar comparatively gets weaker, it takes a little bit more Brazilian reals to buy the same, even though the U.S. dollars are converted to the currency rate, is going in the positive direction for sales. And so when you take a look at it,  it does go in unison but there is a little bit of translational problem there when we're seeing the currency gets stronger.
