componenttextpreview: This is Scott, Im in for Ivy.  I just have a quick question.  Last quarter you guys spoke about benefit from targeting contractors going after foreclosed homes.  I was wondering if you could give an update on that and the incremental change you saw thi
componenttext: This is Scott, Im in for Ivy.  I just have a quick question.  Last quarter you guys spoke about benefit from targeting contractors going after foreclosed homes.  I was wondering if you could give an update on that and the incremental change you saw this quarter?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, I think our comments in the past has been that the nature of the pro doing the work on foreclosed homes, the foreclosed homes that are being purchased by investors probably benefits the multiline warehouse home center more than the specialty paint
componenttext:
Scott, I think our comments in the past has been that the nature of the pro doing the work on foreclosed homes, the foreclosed homes that are being purchased by investors probably benefits the multiline warehouse home center more than the specialty paint store because their needs for materials are much broader than the assortment offered by a specialty paint store.
That doesnt mean that theres no professional painting contractors working on those properties, its just that generally the contractor working on those properties also does some floor coverings, some electrical, some plumbing, etcetera.  
So we think that that channel has probably seen the benefit disproportionate to the paint stores channel.

componenttextpreview: A couple of questions.  First of all, Bob, I think you commented that the input cost inflation for the industry, I thought you said was mid-single digits in the second quarter and it would be higher by the end of the year.  Can you just explain what the i
componenttext: A couple of questions.  First of all, Bob, I think you commented that the input cost inflation for the industry, I thought you said was mid-single digits in the second quarter and it would be higher by the end of the year.  Can you just explain what the input cost year over year was for the industry in the second quarter.  And what the expectation is that that would look like in the second half, if you can do it that way?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, its a timing issue, Eric.  The input costs rolls through the second quarter.  So on average, if you start out at the beginning of the second quarter, most of these raw materials categories were lower than they were by the end of the second quarte
componenttext:
Well, its a timing issue, Eric.  The input costs rolls through the second quarter.  So on average, if you start out at the beginning of the second quarter, most of these raw materials categories were lower than they were by the end of the second quarter.  
So we saw them rise through the second quarter, and you know, where they plateau is hard to predict.  Even if they stayed at the level they are now, youd be in the mid-to-upper single-digit range.  Does that make sense?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah.  I guess more directly, the input cost inflation will be greater in the second half than it was in the second quarter.  Is that right?
componenttext: Yeah.  I guess more directly, the input cost inflation will be greater in the second half than it was in the second quarter.  Is that right?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The answer to that is yes.  And when you sit there and take a look at year over year though, because the [inaudible] were at the low point in the second quarter of 2009 on a year-over-year basis.  The second quarter was hard.
componenttext: The answer to that is yes.  And when you sit there and take a look at year over year though, because the [inaudible] were at the low point in the second quarter of 2009 on a year-over-year basis.  The second quarter was hard.

componenttext: Great.  Thats helpful.  Secondly, in terms of the momentum of sales, if you can just talk about the excluding currency, excluding acquisitions, what that number was again for the second quarter and what the expectations is that that number will look like in the second half so we can just see the underlying business excluding these other things?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think when you take a look at it, what we said in our guidance last quarter was that the acquisitions would be about [inaudible] and then the second, and third, and fourth quarter, but only 1  for the full year because we had only three months, or thr
componenttext:
I think when you take a look at it, what we said in our guidance last quarter was that the acquisitions would be about [inaudible] and then the second, and third, and fourth quarter, but only 1  for the full year because we had only three months, or three quarters against four quarters.  So acquisition came in at 1.9% of our increase.  And we still think, in the guidance, we have around 2% for the acquisition. 
We have not put the next acquisition into the guidance yet.  Were waiting to see - its hard for us to forecast when that will close.  When we look at the currency, we have very little currency in the second half of the year.  When you take a look at the [inaudible] or the Mexican Paso, really the currencies that drive us, when you start looking at that third quarter and fourth quarter, we think that the currency is going to be relatively flat.  
So when we give our guidance, I would say less than 2/10ths of a percent will be currency in 2% each quarter, but 1  of those for a full year will be for acquisitions.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Great.  And then lastly from a tax rate, I think you had talked about mid-30s coming out of the last quarter was a little bit lower.  Apparently some of that may have been influenced by the charge or not.  Can you update us on what the tax rate assumption
componenttext: Great.  And then lastly from a tax rate, I think you had talked about mid-30s coming out of the last quarter was a little bit lower.  Apparently some of that may have been influenced by the charge or not.  Can you update us on what the tax rate assumption should be?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah.  When you take a look at it, you know, we had some discreet items that hit us in the second quarter.  Its hard to really predict when discreet items will hit.  But when we take a look at our full-year forecast, we think, you know, last quarter we
componenttext:
Yeah.  When you take a look at it, you know, we had some discreet items that hit us in the second quarter.  Its hard to really predict when discreet items will hit.  But when we take a look at our full-year forecast, we think, you know, last quarter we think we were talking about the low-to-mid 30s for that tax rate.  
We think probably for the full year, the tax rate will be back in that 33% range.

componenttext: And then lastly, within the slightly softer second half growth versus the second quarter, can you just specifically talk about where youre seeing or expecting that difference to be as adjusted new residential due to the expiration of the tax credit? componenttextpreview: I dont know that we have any specific in-market segments, Eric, its more prominent than others.  Obviously the commercial markets as weve talked about are still lagging and facing a lot of headwind.  And I think theres just been a little bit
componenttext:
I dont know that we have any specific in-market segments, Eric, its more prominent than others.  Obviously the commercial markets as weve talked about are still lagging and facing a lot of headwind.  
And I think theres just been a little bit of a slowdown in some demand in the residential markets.  Guidance in the mid-to-upper single-digits range is still robust given the last four-year track record weve been on.  And with that number, Sean just went through them.  I mean, while were seeing a little bit of a slowdown here, were still fairly bullish on this revenue stream.

componenttext:
In the consumer business you were up roughly 12% for the quarter versus up a percent in the first quarter.  And I know April volumes were really strong, so I take it that thats an unrepresented number going forward.  So should we expect that to diminish? 
And likewise in stores, given that probably there was a real bump up in April, I mean, are the growth rates in those two businesses for the next couple of quarters likely to be lower than what they were in the second quarter, all things being equal?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah.  I think when you take a look at it, when we came out with our guidance for the second quarter, we said high single digits.  We didnt give a range.  And now when you look at the third quarter, were saying mid-to-high and we still the acquisiti
componenttext:
Yeah.  I think when you take a look at it, when we came out with our guidance for the second quarter, we said high single digits.  We didnt give a range.  And now when you look at the third quarter, were saying mid-to-high and we still the acquisition in there.  And for the full year, weve stayed the same.  
So I think that, you know, its pretty easy to assume that different segments are going to be not as high because of the high single digits versus the mid.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think on the consumer specifically, Jeff, youre a real wordsmith.  You saw on Bobs comments here that we talked about the segments retail, industrial and institutional customers.  And this is a part of business we dont talk a lot about, but on
componenttext:
I think on the consumer specifically, Jeff, youre a real wordsmith.  You saw on Bobs comments here that we talked about the segments retail, industrial and institutional customers.  And this is a part of business we dont talk a lot about, but on this segment we have a significant product line of aerosols and coatings that we sell into other types of distribution channels beyond the typical retail partners.  And it was in that space that we saw some really unique and strong performance in the quarter.  
And I think your comment about is this sustainable, this is probably more of a blood [inaudible] and consumer segment will probably come back down in the single-digit range going forward.

componenttext:
Two quick follow-up questions.  The first one is the consumer segments, obviously.  You mentioned several times you delivered very strong results in the quarter.  But one of your major competitors in the retail channel reported the month less robust in trends last week.  
So Im just wondering what contributed to your volume of performance relative to competitors in that channel.  Is that because some market-share wins, or some new contracts, or something like that?

componenttext:
As Shawn commented on the earlier portion, you know, our track record here, and this price increase has been coming in pretty much consistent with cash price increases.  It takes a little while for us to get announcements out to negotiate and start to see the effectiveness.  And some time on the consumer side with that lag, stores start early by full implementation. 
Typically, across all segments we see somewhere in the 70 to 80% implementation.

Good.  Just a couple quick questions.  First off, I guess a little bit more high level.  It looks like, as everyone said, youve kept the guidance the same, but expectations for top line seem to be moderating both from you guys and the rest of the market.  And existing was out today and it was slightly worse than expected. 
What gives you the confidence, I guess, that you can keep the guidance the same?  Is it mainly just the cost side and so on?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you know, if you went back to our full-year guidance on sales for the full year, three months ago we gave guidance for the year.  It was mid-to-high single digits.  So we really havent changed the sales guidance for the year, nor the EPS guidance
componenttext:
Well, you know, if you went back to our full-year guidance on sales for the full year, three months ago we gave guidance for the year.  It was mid-to-high single digits.  So we really havent changed the sales guidance for the year, nor the EPS guidance. 
So we feel our sales are going to come in pretty much where we thought we would be three months ago.

We commented about the SG&A control, the company, the improved efficiency as a result of the top things we did a year or so ago to get some of our plants down.  The margin performance, while down 60 basis points in this rapid raw-material environment with more pricing implementation from previously announce pricing, were confident that well be in that range.

componenttext:
Yeah.  I think when you sit there and take a look at improvement in operating margins, you know, two, three years ago our storage group was over 15 %.  Consumer is not as consistent as store, but its actually been as high as 19 at one time. 
So you know, our thoughts are that eventually were going to get back those levels and go higher.  When you look at the global group, now we believe that eventually well be around 80% of where stores can be, which would tell you that we think its going to be in the low double-digits, low teens.  So when you think about it, thats what were looking for for the segment.

componenttextpreview: Hi.  Good afternoon  I think you guys said that on the new home sales, youre sort of looking at 500,00 to 600,000.  Could you comment on both existing size as well as on the non-resi side?
componenttext: Hi.  Good afternoon  I think you guys said that on the new home sales, youre sort of looking at 500,00 to 600,000.  Could you comment on both existing size as well as on the non-resi side?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah.  Let me deal with non residential first.  In non-residential, square footage put in place through June were down in the mid-20% range.  We think that that rate of decline has moderated somewhat from last year.  We dont think were on bottom yet
componenttext:
Yeah.  Let me deal with non residential first.  In non-residential, square footage put in place through June were down in the mid-20% range.  We think that that rate of decline has moderated somewhat from last year.  We dont think were on bottom yet.  We think thats probably a good number for the balance of the year, is were going to finish the year down in the 20%, 20-plus percent range.  
In terms of sales of existing homes, it certainly softens somewhat also after the expiration of a tax credit because that was driving some resales as well.  What is important to us Robert, in looking at those numbers is not just the sheer volume, but the quality of the transaction.  
Foreclosed and distressed properties being acquired out of foreclosure by investors really doesnt drive our end markets as well as existing home sales by an owner-occupant to a new owner-occupant.  
So to the extend that we can - I mean, if volume is flat from last year, and the quality improves because of the decline in foreclosure transactions, thats good for us.  We know that theres certainly more pain to come in the foreclosure market, but its been fairly orderly and weve seen a steady rise in the quality transactions.  
But a flat number in existing home sales with improving quality would benefit our business.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I got you.  Just one followup on that very point.  I mean, with the modifications that have been going on on the mortgage side, and I think its mixed results.  Maybe people were thinking a little further out, theyre just going to fail again.  My l
componenttext:
I got you.  Just one followup on that very point.  I mean, with the modifications that have been going on on the mortgage side, and I think its mixed results.  Maybe people were thinking a little further out, theyre just going to fail again.  
My last question pertains to the previous question.  You mentioned your key margins were in both the consumer groups as well as the store group.  And that was also a very high [inaudible] and a good quality on the existing, and certainly on the new stuff.  
I guess, Im just thinking about this, I guess youre looking more on the cost side, whether SG&A initiatives or others to offset whats going to be sort of - seems to just a lower volume than what took place three or four years ago.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, I would say its cost, but its also productivity.  It think when you think about the stores group, Bob mentioned that we opened over 160 stores in new markets.  When we take a look at that we had to close some redundant stores.  As we con
componenttext:
You know, I would say its cost, but its also productivity.  It think when you think about the stores group, Bob mentioned that we opened over 160 stores in new markets.  When we take a look at that we had to close some redundant stores.  
As we continue to get more pentitration in markets we get more productivity in markets.  And so when you take a look at the makeup of our stores organization two or three years from now versus three years ago, well have higher store counts and well be more productive.  And we can probably hit the peak margins at weaker sales.  Thats what we believe.  
We also believe the same thing in consumer group.  We think that as we continue to get more productivity, what we have said is that we think we can hit our peak margins without hitting our peak sales.  
And then you look at the global group.  Its the same thing.  As we continue to get more mass in individual countries, were going to be able to get that margin up.  
And on the first part of your question ,clearly there is more pain to come in the housing markets and we haven not called the bottom on the housing markets.  We think that foreclosure activity to come is going to keep pressure on home values and that wont right itself for a while yet.  
We should point out thought that a lot of the vitality were seeing in the residential repaint markets are not so much driven by the traditional drivers, which are existing home turnover, but theyre being driven by pent-up demand from postponed maintenance activity by people who are staying in their house.  And we think that thats whats driving some of the goodness in the market today.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Co.'s Review of Second Quarter 2010 Financial Results and Expectations for the Third Quarter and Full Year. With us on today's call are Chris Connor, Chairman and CEO; Sean Hennessy, Senior Vice Pre
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Co.'s Review of Second Quarter 2010 Financial Results and Expectations for the Third Quarter and Full Year. With us on today's call are Chris Connor, Chairman and CEO; Sean Hennessy, Senior Vice President of Finance and CFO; Allen Mistysyn, Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President, Corporate Communication and Public Affairs. 
This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Vcall via the Internet at www.sherwin.com. An archived replay of this webcast will be available at www.sherwin.com, beginning approximately two hours after this conference call concludes and will be available until Wednesday, August 11, 2010, at 5:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time.
This conference call will include certain forward-looking statements, as defined under U.S. Federal Securities Laws with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statement speaks only as of the date on which such statement is made, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning. After the review of second quarter results, we will open this session to questions. 
I would now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jackie. In order to allow more time for questions, we provided balance sheet items and other selected information on our website at sherwin.com under Investor Relations Second Quarter Press Release.Summarizing overall company performance for the
componenttext:
Thanks, Jackie. In order to allow more time for questions, we provided balance sheet items and other selected information on our website at sherwin.com under Investor Relations Second Quarter Press Release.
Summarizing overall company performance for the second quarter 2010 versus second quarter 2009, consolidated net sales increased $195.2 million or 10% to $2.14 billion, due primarily to improved architectural sales, acquisitions and favorable foreign currency translation rate changes.
Acquisitions increased net sales by 1.9% in the quarter, and favorable currency translation rate increased consolidated net sales 1.3%. Consolidated gross profit dollars increased $76.5 million for the quarter to $971.9 million. Gross margins decreased 60 basis points to 45.4% of sales from 46% in the second quarter last year. Selling, general and administrative expenses for the quarter increased 5.9% to $691.2 million. As a percent of sales, SG&A decreased to 32.3% in the second quarter this year from 33.5% last year. Interest expense increased $16 million compared to the second quarter last year.
Consolidated profit before taxes in the quarter increased $27.1 million or 11.7% to $259.2 million. Our effective tax rate in the second quarter this year was 29.9% compared to 31.9% in the second quarter of 2009. For the full year 2010, we expect our effective tax rate to be approximately 33%.
Consolidated net income increased $23.7 million to $181.7 million from $158 million in the second quarter of 2009. Net income as a percent of sales was 8.5% compared to 8.1% in the second quarter last year. Diluted net income per common share for the quarter increased 21.5% to $1.64 per share from $1.35 per share in 2009. Looking at our results by operating segment, sales for our Paint Stores Group in the second quarter 2010 increased 6.4% to $1.24 billion. Comparable store sales, sales by stores open in more than 12-calendar month, increased 5.9%. The increase in sales for the segment was due to improved domestic Architectural Paint sales, primarily the residential repaint contractors and improving Protective & Marine product sales.
Regionally, in the second quarter, our Eastern division led all divisions, followed by Southeastern division, Midwestern division and Southwestern division. Sales by all four Paint Stores divisions increased in the second quarter compared to last year. Segment profit for the group increased to 9.5% to $212 million in the second quarter of 2010. Segment margin increased to 17% from 16.5% due primarily to higher sales volume and effective SG&A control.  During the second quarter, Paint Stores Group opened seven new stores and closed four redundant store locations.
Turning to our Consumer Group. Sales in the second quarter increased 11.9% to $410.2 million. The increase was due primarily to improving demand at some of the segment's retail, industrial and institutional customers. Segment profit for the Consumer Group increased 22.1% in the quarter to $80.7 million. Segment profit as a percent of external sales increased to 19.7% from 18% in the same period last year, due primarily to effective cost control and cost savings realized from previous year's site rationalizations that were partially offset by raw material cost increases.
For our Global Finishes Group, sales in U.S. dollars increased 18.8% to $486.5 million in the quarter, due primarily to acquisitions, favorable currency rate changes and higher paint sales volume.
For the quarter, acquisitions increased Global Finishes Group net sales by 9.2%, and favorable currency translation rate changes added 5% to net sales in U.S. dollars. Second quarter segment profit increased 28.2% to $40 million, due to higher sales volume, good expense control and currency translation.
The combined effect of positive foreign currency rate changes and the negative impact of acquisitions, including all transaction costs, slightly reduced Global Finishes Group segment profit in the quarter.
Turning to the balance sheet. Our total debt on June 30, 2010, was $908.6 million including total short-term borrowings of $199.5 million. Total debt on June 30, 2009, was $800.7 million. Our cash balance at the end of the quarter was $48.4 million compared $49.3 million at the end of the second quarter 2009. Total borrowings to capitalization were 37.2% at the end of the quarter versus 31.6% at the end of the second quarter last year.
Long-term debt to capitalization was 29.1% at the end of the second quarter this year compared to 11.9% last year. In the second quarter 2010, we spent $22 million on capital expenditures, depreciation expense was $33.1 million, and amortization expense was $6.5 million. For the full year 2010, we anticipate capital expenditures for the year will be approximately $100 million to $115 million, depreciation will be about $147 million, and amortization will be about $26 million.
I'll conclude my remarks on the quarter with a brief update on the status of our lead pigment litigation. In California, the state's Supreme Court will decide whether it be permissible for cities and counties to retain contingency counsel to aid them in their suit against former manufacturers of lead pigment. Briefing is completed, oral argument was held on May 5, 2010, and we expect a decision some time this summer. 
The Gaines case, a single-plaintiff personal injury suit, was tried to a jury in Jefferson County, Mississippi, beginning in June of 2009. The jury returned a verdict in favor of the plaintiff. The company has filed a notice of appeal with the Mississippi Supreme Court, and briefing has now begun. We recently filed our opening brief. We expect plaintiff to file their brief within the next 60 days at which time, we will have an opportunity to file a reply brief. No hearing date has been set yet, and a decision is not expected until at least late 2010 or early 2011.
That concludes our review of results for the second quarter 2010. So I'll turn the call over to Chris Connor, who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for the third quarter and full year. Chris?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. The second quarter of 2010 was a solid quarter for Sherwin-Williams in many respects. It was our strongest quarter in terms of sales growth in the last four years, dating back to the f
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. The second quarter of 2010 was a solid quarter for Sherwin-Williams in many respects. It was our strongest quarter in terms of sales growth in the last four years, dating back to the first quarter of 2006. After backing out acquisitions and positive currency translations, revenues increased nearly 7% versus the second quarter of last year. Our Domestic Architectural Paint business improved across all end-user segments, led by particularly strong volume gains in the residential repaint market. Domestic and international sales of Automotive Finishes, OEM Product Finishes and Protective & Marine coatings also rebounded nicely in the quarter compared to the second quarter of last year.
It was a solid quarter in terms of earnings improvement as well. Although we did experience some year-over-year gross margin compression resulting from a rapid increase in raw material cost, primarily acrylic latex and titanium dioxide, and higher operating costs we incurred to compensate for the poor service performance of a major raw material supplier. These included the cost of transferring of raw materials between manufacturing plants, moving finished goods between distribution centers and between stores, lower plant productivity due to raw material outages, and higher-cost spot buy to compensate our poor service level. Although these raw material supply problems are being resolved as we speak, many of these higher costs will continue to pressure our margins in the near term. We have them responding to the mounting raw material cost pressures by corporately tightening SG&A expense control and raising prices where necessary. SG&A as a percent of sales for the quarter decreased 120 basis points compared to last year, which is noteworthy considering the incremental service expense required to support double-digit sales growth.
All three of our reportable segments posted strong operating margin increases in the quarter. Combined profit for the three segments increased by $42 million, more than 14%, and combined segment profit margin increased 60 basis points to 15.5%.
Our interest expense for the quarter increased by $16 million over last year, as we took advantage of an opportunity to repurchase $85 million in long-term debt. In this particular case, long-term means bonds maturing in 2097. The financial metrics were favorable, and this repurchase allows for greater flexibility for our balance sheet, going forward. The decision to take advantage of this opportunity impacted our earnings performance for the quarter by $0.08 and will be reflected in our guidance estimate for our total year earnings as well.
Despite the gross margins pressure I mentioned earlier and the higher interest expense, our consolidated net income for the quarter rose 15%, and diluted earnings per common share increased 21.5%. In the first six months of 2010, we generated $211 million in net operating cash, as we're down slightly from the $250 million range in the first half of last year, due primarily to $78 million increase in accounts receivable as the result of higher sales. We continue to invest this company's cash to expand our control of distribution platform, complete suitable acquisitions as well as purchase shares of our stock for treasury.
Turning to first six months of the year, our Paint Stores Group opened 13 new store locations and consolidated seven redundant stores. We finished the quarter with 3,360 stores in operation compared to 3,340 this time last year. Once again for the full year, we expect to open between 40 and 50 new stores and slow the pace of redundant store closings. Over the past two and a half years, our net store count has increased by 35 stores, but it was 35, the hard way. During this time, we've opened 166 store locations in new markets and closed 131 redundant locations, primarily stores that we acquired over the past six years that were located in close proximity to existing Sherwin-Williams stores. The exposure to new markets we achieve would be the 166 new store openings that's given us the significant advantage in reaching new customers as well as servicing existing ones.
On April 1, we completed the acquisition of Arch Chemicals' industrial wood coatings business which trade under the Sayerlack brand name. In late May, we announced the definitive agreement to acquire  Becker Acroma, one of the largest global manufacturers of industrial wood coatings. These two European-based companies with combined annual sales of approximately $450 million serve the joinery, kitchen cabinet, furniture and wood flooring industries worldwide. They represent another important step in our efforts to strengthen our growing global industrial coatings platform to better serve our customers around the world with outstanding assets, technology and people.
During the quarter, we used the company's cash to buy back 1.95 million shares of our common stock in the open market, preliminary year-to-date total of 2.35 million shares. In June 30, we have remaining board authorization to purchase $8.4 million shares of stock.
We remain cautiously optimistic about the resilience of the architectural repaint market in the Americas and global demand for most industrial coatings. Our outlook for the third quarter of 2010, just for consolidated net sales to increase in the mid-to-high single-digit percentage compared to last year's third quarter with sales at this level, we expect diluted net income per common share to be in the range of $1.55 to $1.70 per share compared to $1.51 per share in 2009.
For the full year of 2010, we expect consolidated net sales to increase in the mid-to-high single-digit percentage range compared to last year. With the annual sales of that level, we are updating our diluted net income per common share expectation to be in the range of $4.12 to $4.52 per share compared to $3.78 per share last year. As a reminder, our full year guidance includes the $0.08 per share charge for the higher interest expense in the second quarter, as well as the $0.10 per share charge taken in the first quarter related to the healthcare legislation.
Finally, earlier this week, our board declared a regular quarterly dividend of $0.36 per share, up from $0.355 last year, keeping us on track to achieve our 32nd consecutive year of increased dividends. Again, thanks for joining us this morning, and we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Here again, Kevin, we've been very consistent about our pricing philosophy here at the company, when facing raw material pressures, as this is a reminder for the entire audience. We, first, pushed back against the supplier; secondarily, look internally to
componenttext: Here again, Kevin, we've been very consistent about our pricing philosophy here at the company, when facing raw material pressures, as this is a reminder for the entire audience. We, first, pushed back against the supplier; secondarily, look internally to see what efficiencies we can gain; and then finally, take pricing to the market as a last resort. We've been very open with the investment community group regarding those pricing actions after we've announced them to our customers in terms of timing and percentage. At this point in time, we're not commenting on any pricing activities planned in any of our segments for the second half.

componenttext: No, I think for the remainder of the year, we're looking our 100-year notes. If there's an opportunity, we need to bring some of that in at pretty favorable rates. But for the current year, I don't think you're going to see us do that, bring any more in.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then when we look at the interplay between volume growth in the quarter with the gross margin decline and the SG&A ratio decline, could you talk about what was going on there including benefits of that bringing leverage and some of the cost reductions
componenttext: And then when we look at the interplay between volume growth in the quarter with the gross margin decline and the SG&A ratio decline, could you talk about what was going on there including benefits of that bringing leverage and some of the cost reductions you've taken over the past 18 to 24 months?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the gross margin, as you indicated when we take a look at the kind of benefits we've had from taking the right size in our footprint, I think that we're down 6/10 in our gross margin. But the raws, when you take at the raws' selling price and the
componenttext: I think the gross margin, as you indicated when we take a look at the kind of benefits we've had from taking the right size in our footprint, I think that we're down 6/10 in our gross margin. But the raws, when you take at the raws' selling price and the whole mixture, we feel pretty good about how our conversion costs came in. Our SG&A was, in the second quarter, was up right around $38 million, but we did have the acquisition in there. And without the acquisition, we felt pretty good because our SG&A grew to less than half of what our sales rate did. So when you take a look at it, our SG&A was now 1.2%, and I think that's really what shows the strength of the leverage when we did a 10% sales gain that we can drive that PBT, up 21%.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sean, how does the volume growth help the cost of goods line? Obviously, there's cost pressure but can you get into a little bit with the volumes?
componenttext: Sean, how does the volume growth help the cost of goods line? Obviously, there's cost pressure but can you get into a little bit with the volumes?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We've always said that the incremental volume really helps Consumer. And when you look at the Consumer Group, our operating margins which were up from, we're up fairly strong in the second quarter and year-to-date, with the plans running at full capacity.
componenttext: We've always said that the incremental volume really helps Consumer. And when you look at the Consumer Group, our operating margins which were up from, we're up fairly strong in the second quarter and year-to-date, with the plans running at full capacity. That helps us. We've never gotten into the metric of what our conversion cost is on the incremental gallon. But if you think about incremental gallon, the gross profit of over 40%, and when you take a look at it, the incremental cost of SG&A and admin, especially in admin, is basically zero, so the incremental gallons really flowed down to the bottom line.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Robert Koort of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Robert Koort of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, I think in the last quarter, you talked about  maybe the clouds were starting to lift a little bit. Now you talked about a little deceleration here in May and June. Do you think that's directly attributable to the tax issues, or there's something b
componenttext: Chris, I think in the last quarter, you talked about  maybe the clouds were starting to lift a little bit. Now you talked about a little deceleration here in May and June. Do you think that's directly attributable to the tax issues, or there's something broader that might extend this bit of malaise here or lull, if you will, into the second half?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Bob, obviously, while that was a piece of it, I don't think that explains the entire slowing. We've commented about the skittish consumer in this economy that any little bit of bad news tends to see some bit of a pullback in some of this discretiona
componenttext: Well, Bob, obviously, while that was a piece of it, I don't think that explains the entire slowing. We've commented about the skittish consumer in this economy that any little bit of bad news tends to see some bit of a pullback in some of this discretionary spending. We have commented earlier, at the beginning of the year, about the increasing headwind that we're going to face on the new construction in Non-Residential businesses. And those are continuing and, in fact, the housing numbers came out and adjusted down a little bit as well, too. So there's a broader stage slowing, we see, to the demand for end products here in the United States across a lot of segments.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: How would you adjust, if at all, your plans for store count next year, as the trends play out?
componenttext: How would you adjust, if at all, your plans for store count next year, as the trends play out?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We've always taken a long-term view of that, Bob. We've talked repeatedly to the investment community that our next short-term horizon goal was to get 4,000 Paint Stores in North America. We're on a continued path to do that. The 40 to 50 gross new stores
componenttext: We've always taken a long-term view of that, Bob. We've talked repeatedly to the investment community that our next short-term horizon goal was to get 4,000 Paint Stores in North America. We're on a continued path to do that. The 40 to 50 gross new stores we're planning for this year has been the low end of our range. I don't see us dropping below the low end of that for next year. And then, as the economy improves, we would probably ramp back up to a more normalized run rate of about 100 new storage per year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Was there a difference in the typical approach to pricing, the timing of price increases this year, or was 2010 a normal sequence in terms of when you institute those prices?
componenttext: Was there a difference in the typical approach to pricing, the timing of price increases this year, or was 2010 a normal sequence in terms of when you institute those prices?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely normal in terms of the sequence or the process that we go through. The only abnormal part of that was that we raised in April 1 for our Architectural businesses, as opposed to the beginning of the year, and the reason was, is because we were fo
componenttext: Absolutely normal in terms of the sequence or the process that we go through. The only abnormal part of that was that we raised in April 1 for our Architectural businesses, as opposed to the beginning of the year, and the reason was, is because we were following the very disciplined approach we take here, which is to make sure that we have clear visibility of the cost, that we've got everything we can to mitigate it. We didn't see that late in the fourth quarter of last year, which took a path under first quarter pricing. By the time the first quarter stiffened, we realized we needed to go out. So that was very much the process that we went through to get this earlier price increase announced, and our future price increases will probably have the same mindset.

componenttextpreview: I think if you've got that in front of you, Saul, you have the Consumer Group for the three months is up, $423 million from $356 million. Global Finishes were down $48 million versus $30 million. You have to put those two numbers together. There were some
componenttext: I think if you've got that in front of you, Saul, you have the Consumer Group for the three months is up, $423 million from $356 million. Global Finishes were down $48 million versus $30 million. You have to put those two numbers together. There were some products that the Global Finishes Group used to make and transfer to stores that the Consumer Group is now making. So if you put those two together, you have the $404 million versus $453 million, so that takes your percentage down to about 10%. The Consumer Group also made some products for the Global Group. So they'll not jump 100% to the Stores Group anymore.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010

componenttext: So there's no build-up in inventory, as far as the Global Group as a result of that?

componenttext: No. In fact, if you look at our total inventory $793 million versus $769 million, almost 100% of that is related to the acquisition that we booked this quarter.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Today's raw materials shortages you have experienced in the quarter, you're getting better or worse in the third quarter? Can you provide a little bit more color acrylic acid in gas [ph] (39:03)...
componenttext: Today's raw materials shortages you have experienced in the quarter, you're getting better or worse in the third quarter? Can you provide a little bit more color acrylic acid in gas [ph] (39:03)...

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we made a comment that these issues are getting resolved. The raw material chain of monomers has strengthened during the quarter. Our suppliers are catching up. We're seeing improvement, although catching up in the middle of the paint season is a
componenttext: I think we made a comment that these issues are getting resolved. The raw material chain of monomers has strengthened during the quarter. Our suppliers are catching up. We're seeing improvement, although catching up in the middle of the paint season is a difficult thing to accomplish. So we think we're going to feel the tightness for the remainder of the year. Probably, catching up significantly back to normal run rates in the fourth quarter, early first quarter of next year. So to the point that there'll be some tightness in the third quarter, company will continue to take the remedial actions that we've been taking to maintain service to our customers, and we'll just hope to see that improve as time goes on.

componenttext: I think that they're in appropriate shape. These are excellent business people who have sophisticated programs and systems in place to keep their inventory to appropriate level. I don't think there's any overstocking or destocking that's been occurring. I'd say it's pretty much as it should be at this point in time.

componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, with the announcement of these two industrial wood coatings activities in Europe, a little stronger year for the company than the past couple of years. We have indicated that we continue to have an interest in using cash for our corporate
componenttext: Yes, obviously, with the announcement of these two industrial wood coatings activities in Europe, a little stronger year for the company than the past couple of years. We have indicated that we continue to have an interest in using cash for our corporate acquisitions where we can strengthen our controlled distribution and architectural store model, both domestically and around the world, as well as building out our Industrial Coatings service capabilities. There are a number of those opportunities that we're looking at it as we speak. And it would be inappropriate to comment on it at this point in time.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from P.J. Juvekar of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from P.J. Juvekar of Citigroup.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Chuck, are you able to gain share in the stores business? Is that what's driving your gross here? Because some of your competitors, smaller competitors seem to be less focus on their store business.
componenttext: Chuck, are you able to gain share in the stores business? Is that what's driving your gross here? Because some of your competitors, smaller competitors seem to be less focus on their store business.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, we've talked to a great deal about the importance of that distribution platform for our story, P.J. And as you also know, our focus -- in primary customer segment is through the professional painting contractor. It seems the improving t
componenttext: Well, as you know, we've talked to a great deal about the importance of that distribution platform for our story, P.J. And as you also know, our focus -- in primary customer segment is through the professional painting contractor. It seems the improving trends that we're seeing are the result of the contractor coming back a little bit this year. We see them hiring painters and lining up more work, their schedules are more robust than they have been. The residential repaint market as we indicated at the beginning of the year would be the driver for this group this year, and that's proving to be the case as the year is unfolding. So to the extent that we remain focused on the contractor, we're enjoying a little bit of a bounce back in that business this year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And can you split your business in terms of volumes, the new segments and does it sort of bring down these days between new construction repaint and maybe commercial activity?
componenttext: And can you split your business in terms of volumes, the new segments and does it sort of bring down these days between new construction repaint and maybe commercial activity?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I can do that for the industry P.J. and we're not too far off industry numbers. We think that new construction in total in the U.S. in terms of architectural volume is down probably in the low teens now. So it's 12%, 13% of total gallon volume goes to new
componenttext: I can do that for the industry P.J. and we're not too far off industry numbers. We think that new construction in total in the U.S. in terms of architectural volume is down probably in the low teens now. So it's 12%, 13% of total gallon volume goes to new construction and that's roughly half and half non-residential and residential. Residential maybe a little bit higher than non-residential. In the repaint market, the other 87%, 88%, residential is probably 70% of that, non-residential 30%. Relative to the market, we'd probably skew a little heavier toward new construction and a little heavier towards non-residential.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, you talked about price growth of average about 2%, is it fair to say that maybe consumer channel is kind of flattish and maybe store is looking up 5% and it averages out to 2%? Would that be in the ballpark?
componenttext: And then secondly, you talked about price growth of average about 2%, is it fair to say that maybe consumer channel is kind of flattish and maybe store is looking up 5% and it averages out to 2%? Would that be in the ballpark?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's why a lot of times, we never have tried to give you a total, because when consumer they have aerosol cans, brushes, rollers and so forth. That's a tough one to give to you, that's why we've never gone to the full. But in general, I would say w
componenttext: Yes, that's why a lot of times, we never have tried to give you a total, because when consumer they have aerosol cans, brushes, rollers and so forth. That's a tough one to give to you, that's why we've never gone to the full. But in general, I would say when you -- that the price increases at the stores group typically go in faster and are more effective earlier than we realize them into consumer group and since we went out April 1, that's probably still true to this day also.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010

componenttext: And just lastly, Chuck, you talked about second quarter being hit hard by raw materials? Can you just give us some idea about what kind of raw materials [indiscernible] you get as to all this acrylic shortages and all of that balance out?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the comment was that we've been working hard to mitigate some tightness in the supply chain in getting through that. We are looking forward for the relief to come primarily in the latexes, and that's been where a lot of tightness has been and some
componenttext:
I think the comment was that we've been working hard to mitigate some tightness in the supply chain in getting through that. We are looking forward for the relief to come primarily in the latexes, and that's been where a lot of tightness has been and some of the additives that come off of that chemical chain.
I think that was pretty broadly discussed in the industry in the second quarter and as those raw materials that supply those industries have caught up, we're seeing some catch up as well. In terms of the other core raw materials, packaging, other types of solvents, et cetera, we're in fine shape there.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finally here, can you talk about -- have you been doing anything in terms of store lease negotiations, I mean, the market condition here pretty weak. Have there been opportunities to renew at favorable rates or get any sort of concessions?
componenttext: And then just finally here, can you talk about -- have you been doing anything in terms of store lease negotiations, I mean, the market condition here pretty weak. Have there been opportunities to renew at favorable rates or get any sort of concessions?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've been doing that over the last really over two years now, and we've had different things and instead of just, we call the standard lease, I think we've looked for different aspects of contracts and least language that we can get -- that
componenttext: Yes, I think we've been doing that over the last really over two years now, and we've had different things and instead of just, we call the standard lease, I think we've looked for different aspects of contracts and least language that we can get -- that can help us for us long-term. Sometimes that's longer -- that's more options. Sometimes that's a options at a lower-price or renew an option at a lower price and within the least. And then also looking for terms, favorable terms such whether it's common area maintenance or other type of aspects that we can get. So it's been -- we've done probably well over the last two years.

componenttext: I don't know anything about any future price increases, but just to fully understand, you did April 1 with the price increase. You saw just over 2% in this quarter, is it fair to say with the normal lag that we should expect to see something more than that into the third and fourth quarters if everything else is constant?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think that's the -- as each quarter goes by, we'll get a higher and higher percentage of what we [indiscernible].
componenttext: Yes, and I think that's the -- as each quarter goes by, we'll get a higher and higher percentage of what we [indiscernible].

componenttext: And how much have you gotten it so far?

componenttext: Well, we went out with 3% to 5% and if you sit there and take a look at the 2% over 2%, you're talking the midpoint being 4%, we're over 50%.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then second is we've seen DIY take a bigger shift to the market in the last couple of years and you guys that obviously is my [ph] (48:52) great trade, but do you see any trends there that this time you started to pick up your DIY business or is that
componenttext: And then second is we've seen DIY take a bigger shift to the market in the last couple of years and you guys that obviously is my [ph] (48:52) great trade, but do you see any trends there that this time you started to pick up your DIY business or is that still underperforming the real trend that's on your paint source group?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you asking, Greg, about the shift between DIY and the PRO or more of our DIY performance inside?
componenttext: Are you asking, Greg, about the shift between DIY and the PRO or more of our DIY performance inside?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually both. The market shift between DIY and PRO and then within your own business how you think you're doing in DIY.
componenttext: Actually both. The market shift between DIY and PRO and then within your own business how you think you're doing in DIY.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the market shift as we indicated will start to come back towards the Pro as markets improved certainly as new construction would come back a little bit. And we do expect as Bob just answered it in our earlier comment that when the year has said an
componenttext: I think the market shift as we indicated will start to come back towards the Pro as markets improved certainly as new construction would come back a little bit. And we do expect as Bob just answered it in our earlier comment that when the year has said and done, the new residential construction market will be slightly positive for the year. So we're going to start to see a little rebound in those areas. And we've also commented on the discussions that the anecdotal evidence, the contractors in our stores with more work, buying equipment, hiring clothes, et cetera, would indicate that, that's starting to come back a little bit. So we remain bullish on this contractor segment, we think that 60%, 40% range and it's been bouncing around in the last couple of years is probably a pretty reliable number, the kind of ongoing forward, and it should strengthen as the new construction comes back, certainly in the coming years on the commercial side as well. Regarding our own DIY performance, I think we've been pleased to see the numbers in our consumer segment. This quarter, which have a lot of DIY presence there so that's been strong for them, as well as the DIY performance at our own stores. So we got our comp stores 105 plus percent performance, all customer segments are moving in the right direction, so we're getting some lift from DIY as well.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Our Next question is coming from Ivy Zelman of Zelman and Associates.
componenttext: Our Next question is coming from Ivy Zelman of Zelman and Associates.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Scott Rednor on for Ivy. I just have a quick question, last quarter, you guys talked about benefit from targeting contractors going after your foreclosed homes. I was wondering if you could give an update on that, any incremental trends you saw th
componenttext: This is Scott Rednor on for Ivy. I just have a quick question, last quarter, you guys talked about benefit from targeting contractors going after your foreclosed homes. I was wondering if you could give an update on that, any incremental trends you saw this quarter?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think our comments in the past has been that the nature of the Pro doing the work on foreclosed homes, I think foreclosed homes that are being purchased by investors, probably benefit on the multiline warehouse home center more than the specialty paint
componenttext: I think our comments in the past has been that the nature of the Pro doing the work on foreclosed homes, I think foreclosed homes that are being purchased by investors, probably benefit on the multiline warehouse home center more than the specialty paint store. Because their needs for materials are much broader in those offers -- than the -- the assortment offers by a specialty paint store. And that doesn't mean that there's no professional painting contractors working on those properties. It's just that, generally, that contractor working on those properties also does some floor coverings, some electrical, some plumbing et cetera. So we think that, that channel has probably seen the benefit disproportionate to the paintbrush channel.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Eric Bosshard of Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Eric Bosshard of Cleveland Research.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, Bob, I think you commented that the input cost inflation for the industry, I thought you said it was mid-single digit in the second quarter and it would be higher by the end of the year, can you just explain what the input cost year-over-yea
componenttext: First of all, Bob, I think you commented that the input cost inflation for the industry, I thought you said it was mid-single digit in the second quarter and it would be higher by the end of the year, can you just explain what the input cost year-over-year was for the industry in the second quarter, and what the expectation is that, that would look like in the second half if you can do it that way?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a timing issue, Eric. The input cost rose through the second quarter. So on average, it started out at the beginning of the second quarter. They were -- mostly the raw material categories were lower than they were by the end of the second quarter. So
componenttext: It's a timing issue, Eric. The input cost rose through the second quarter. So on average, it started out at the beginning of the second quarter. They were -- mostly the raw material categories were lower than they were by the end of the second quarter. So we saw them rise through the second quarter and where they plateau is hard to predict, but even if they say that the level of they are now, you'd be in the mid-upper single-digit range. Does that make sense?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, more directly. The  input costs inflation will be greater in the second half than it was in the second quarter? Is that right?
componenttext: Yes, I guess, more directly. The  input costs inflation will be greater in the second half than it was in the second quarter? Is that right?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The answer to that is yes, and when you sit there and take a look at the year-over-year, though, because it's the raws were at the low point in the second quarter of 2009. It's probably on a year-over-year basis, the second quarter was our hardest.
componenttext: The answer to that is yes, and when you sit there and take a look at the year-over-year, though, because it's the raws were at the low point in the second quarter of 2009. It's probably on a year-over-year basis, the second quarter was our hardest.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, in terms of the momentum of sales, if you can just talk about the excluding currency, excluding acquisitions, what that number was again for the second quarter and what the expectation of that, that number will look like in the second half so we
componenttext: Secondly, in terms of the momentum of sales, if you can just talk about the excluding currency, excluding acquisitions, what that number was again for the second quarter and what the expectation of that, that number will look like in the second half so we can just see the underlying business excluding these other things?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think when you take a look at it, what we've said in our guidance last quarter was that the acquisitions would be about and then the second, and third, and fourth quarter, but only 1.5% for the full year, because we had only three months against -- thre
componenttext: I think when you take a look at it, what we've said in our guidance last quarter was that the acquisitions would be about and then the second, and third, and fourth quarter, but only 1.5% for the full year, because we had only three months against -- three quarters against four quarters. So acquisition came in at 1.9% of our increase. And we still think, in the guidance, we have around 2% for the acquisition. We have not put the next acquisition into the guidance yet. We're waiting to see -- it's hard for us to forecast when that will close. When we look at the currency, we have very little currency in the second half of the year. When you take a look at the Brazilian real or the Mexican peso, really the currencies that drive us. When you start looking at that third quarter to third quarter and fourth quarter to fourth quarter, we think that the currency is going to be relatively flat. So when we give our guidance, I would say less than 0.2% will be currency and 2% each quarter, but 1.5% for the full year will be for acquisitions.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, from a tax rate, I think you had talked about mid-30s coming out of the last quarter. This quarter's tax rate was a little bit lower, apparently, some of that may have been influenced by the charge on that. Can you update us on what the t
componenttext: And then lastly, from a tax rate, I think you had talked about mid-30s coming out of the last quarter. This quarter's tax rate was a little bit lower, apparently, some of that may have been influenced by the charge on that. Can you update us on what the tax rate assumption should be?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you take a look at it, we had some discreet items that hit us in the second quarter, it's hard to [indiscernible] really predict when discreet items will hit. But when we take a look at our full-year forecast, we think -- last quarter we think w
componenttext: Yes. When you take a look at it, we had some discreet items that hit us in the second quarter, it's hard to [indiscernible] really predict when discreet items will hit. But when we take a look at our full-year forecast, we think -- last quarter we think we were talking about the low to mid-thirties for that tax rate. We think probably for the full year, the tax rate would be back in that 33% range.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, within the slightly softer second half growth versus the second quarter, can you just specifically talk about where you're seeing or expecting that difference to be as adjusted new residential due to the expiration of the tax credit? Or c
componenttext: And then lastly, within the slightly softer second half growth versus the second quarter, can you just specifically talk about where you're seeing or expecting that difference to be as adjusted new residential due to the expiration of the tax credit? Or can you talk about where else you're seeing that or you're expecting that?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know we have any specific in-market segment, Eric, it's more prominent than others, obviously, the commercial markets as we've talked about are still lagging and facing a lot of headwind. And I think there's just been a little bit of a slowdo
componenttext: Yes. I don't know we have any specific in-market segment, Eric, it's more prominent than others, obviously, the commercial markets as we've talked about are still lagging and facing a lot of headwind. And I think there's just been a little bit of a slowdown in some demand in the residential markets. Guidance in the mid-to-upper single-digits range is still robust given the last four-year track record we've been on. And with less FX in that number Sean just went through, I mean, while we're seeing a little bit of a slowdown here, we're still fairly bullish on this revenue stream.

componenttext: In Consumer business, you were up roughly 12% from the quarter versus up 1% in the first quarter. And I know April volumes were really strong, so I take it as that's an unrepresentative number going forward. So should we expect that to diminish and likewise, in Stores, given that probably there was a real pump up in April, I mean, are the growth rates in those two businesses for the next couple of quarters slightly to be lower than what they were in the second quarter all thing being equal?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think when you take a look at it, when we came out our guidance for the second quarter, we set high-single digits. We didn't give a range and now when you look at the third quarter, we're seeing mid-to-high and we still have the acquisition in ther
componenttext: Yes. I think when you take a look at it, when we came out our guidance for the second quarter, we set high-single digits. We didn't give a range and now when you look at the third quarter, we're seeing mid-to-high and we still have the acquisition in there. And for the full year, we stayed the same. So I think that -- it's pretty easy to assume that the different segments are going to be not as high because of the high-single digits versus the mid-to-single.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I think on the Consumer specifically, Jeff, if you're a real wordsmith, you saw on Bob's comments here that we've talked about the segments retail, industrial and institutional customers. And this is a part of business we don't talk a lot about, but on th
componenttext: I think on the Consumer specifically, Jeff, if you're a real wordsmith, you saw on Bob's comments here that we've talked about the segments retail, industrial and institutional customers. And this is a part of business we don't talk a lot about, but on this segment, we have a significant product line of aerosols and coatings that we sell into other types of distribution channels beyond the typical retail partners. And it was in that space that we saw some really unique and strong performance in the quarter.  And I think your comment about this is sustainable, this is probably more of a blip for us and the Consumer segment will probably come back down in the single-digit range going forward.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you went back to our full-year guidance on sales for the full year, three months ago, we gave guidance for the year. It was mid-to-high single digits. So we really haven't changed the sales guidance for the year, nor the EPS guidance that gain ne
componenttext: Well, if you went back to our full-year guidance on sales for the full year, three months ago, we gave guidance for the year. It was mid-to-high single digits. So we really haven't changed the sales guidance for the year, nor the EPS guidance that gain needs calibration [ph] (1:06:45). So we still feel our sales are going to come in pretty much where we thought we would be three months ago.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the other leverage that are played here, Arun [ph] (1:07:03), are in good shape. We've commented about the SG&A control, the company, the improved efficiency as a result of the top things we did a year or so ago to get some of our plants dow
componenttext: Well, I think the other leverage that are played here, Arun [ph] (1:07:03), are in good shape. We've commented about the SG&A control, the company, the improved efficiency as a result of the top things we did a year or so ago to get some of our plants down. The margin performance, while down 60 basis points in this rapid raw-material rising environment with more pricing implementation from previously announced pricing to go. We're confident that we'll be in that range.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think when you sit there and take a look at improvement in operating margins, two, three years ago our Stores Group was over 15.5%. Consumer is not as consistent as Store, but it's actually -- it's been as high as 19% at one time. So our thoughts a
componenttext: Yes. I think when you sit there and take a look at improvement in operating margins, two, three years ago our Stores Group was over 15.5%. Consumer is not as consistent as Store, but it's actually -- it's been as high as 19% at one time. So our thoughts are that eventually we're going to get back those levels and go higher. When you look at the Global Group, now we believe that eventually we'll be at around 80% of where Stores can be, which would tell you that we think it's going to be in the low double-digits, low teens. So when you think about it, that's what we're looking for the segment.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Over one term, when we look at those type of things, we believe that there will be some sales growth but we still think we can get a margin improvement in moderate sales growth.
componenttext: Over one term, when we look at those type of things, we believe that there will be some sales growth but we still think we can get a margin improvement in moderate sales growth.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me deal with non-residential first. In non-residential, square footage put in place through June were down in the mid-20% range. We think that, that rate of decline has moderated somewhat from last year. We don't think we're on bottom yet. We think th
componenttext: Let me deal with non-residential first. In non-residential, square footage put in place through June were down in the mid-20% range. We think that, that rate of decline has moderated somewhat from last year. We don't think we're on bottom yet. We think that's probably a good number for the balance of the year is we're going to finish the year down in the 20%, 20-plus percent range. In terms of sales of existing homes, it certainly softens somewhat also after the expiration of the tax credit, because that was driving some resales as well. What is important to us, Robert, in looking at those numbers is not just the sheer volume, but the quality of the transaction. Foreclosed and distressed properties being acquired out of foreclosure by investors really doesn't drive our end markets, as well as existing home sales by an owner-occupant to a new owner-occupant. So to the extent that we can -- I mean, if volume is flat from last year, and the quality improves because of the decline in foreclosure transactions, that's good for us. We know that there's certainly more pain to come in the foreclosure market, but it's been fairly orderly and we've seen a steady rise in the quality transactions. But a flat number in existing home sales with improving quality would benefit our business.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say it's cost, but it's also productivity. I think when you think about the Stores Group, Bob mentioned that we opened over 160 stores in new markets. When we take a look at that we have to close some redundant stores, as we continue to get more p
componenttext: I would say it's cost, but it's also productivity. I think when you think about the Stores Group, Bob mentioned that we opened over 160 stores in new markets. When we take a look at that we have to close some redundant stores, as we continue to get more penetration in markets we get more productivity in markets. And so when you take a look at the make up of our store's organization two, three years from now versus three years ago, we'll have higher store count and we'll be more productive. And we can probably hit the peak margins at weaker sales. That's what we believe. We also believe the same thing in Consumer Group. We think that as we continue to get more productivity, what we've said is that we think we can hit our peak margins without hitting our peak sale. And then you look at the Global Group, it's the same thing as we continue to get more mass in individual countries, we're going to be able to get that margin up.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And on the first part of your question, clearly, there is more pain to come in the housing market and we haven not called the bottom on the housing markets. We think that foreclosure activity to come is going to keep pressure on home values and that won't
componenttext: And on the first part of your question, clearly, there is more pain to come in the housing market and we haven not called the bottom on the housing markets. We think that foreclosure activity to come is going to keep pressure on home values and that won't write itself for a while yet. We should point out though that a lot of the vitality we're seeing in the residential repaint markets are not so much driven by the traditional drivers, which are existing home turnover, but they're being driven by pent-up demand from postponed maintenance activity by people who are staying in their house. And we think that, that's what's driving some of the goodness in the market today.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010

componenttext: I'd like to hand the floor back to management for any closing comments.
