headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining The Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of the Third Quarter 2010 Financial Results and Expectations for the Full Year. With us on today's call are Chris Connor, Chairman and CEO; Sean Hennessy, Senior Vice President of F
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining The Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of the Third Quarter 2010 Financial Results and Expectations for the Full Year. With us on today's call are Chris Connor, Chairman and CEO; Sean Hennessy, Senior Vice President of Finance and CFO; Al Mistysyn, Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President, Corporate Communications and Public Affairs. 
This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Vcall via the Internet at www.sherwin.com. An archived replay of this webcast will be available at www.sherwin.com beginning approximately two hours after this conference call concludes and will be available until Monday, November 15, 2010, at 5 p.m. Eastern time. 
This conference call will include certain forward-looking statements, as defined under U.S. federal securities laws, with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statement speaks only as of the date on which such statement is made, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning. After the review of third quarter results, we will open this session to questions. 
I will now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Claudia. In order to allow more time for questions, we've provided balance sheet items and other selected information on our website at www.sherwin.com under Investor Relations Third Quarter press release. Summarizing overall company performa
componenttext:
Thank you, Claudia. In order to allow more time for questions, we've provided balance sheet items and other selected information on our website at www.sherwin.com under Investor Relations Third Quarter press release. 
Summarizing overall company performance for the third quarter 2010 versus third quarter '09, consolidated net sales increased $175.4 million or 8.8% to $2.172 billion due primarily to acquisitions, selling price increases, higher sales volume and favorable foreign currency translation rate changes. Favorable currency translation increased consolidated net sales 0.6% in the quarter, and acquisitions increased net sales by 3.4%. 
Consolidated gross profit dollars increased $42.6 million to $971.6 million. Gross margin decreased 180 basis points to 44.7% of sales from 46.5% in the third quarter last year. The decrease in gross margin was primarily due to higher year-over-year raw material prices, which included certain spot market material purchases tied to supplier plant shutdowns.
Selling, general and administrative expenses for the quarter increased 7.6% to $703.7 million due primarily to incremental SG&A from acquisitions, currency translation rate changes, higher service costs resulting from increased sales and higher freight and distribution costs to maintain customer service levels. As a percent of sales, SG&A decreased to 32.4% in the third quarter this year from 32.8% last year. 
Net interest expense increased $2.8 million compared to the third quarter last year. Consolidated profit before taxes in the quarter decreased $3.3 million or 1.3% to $255.4 million. Profit before tax decreased as a percent of sales to 11.8% from 13% last year. 
Our effective tax rate in the third quarter this year was 31.4% compared to 32.3% in the third quarter of 2009. For the full year 2010, we expect our effective tax rate to increase slightly to 32% compared to last year's rate of approximately 30%.
Consolidated net income was essentially flat at $175.3 million compared to $175.2 million in the third quarter of 2009. Net income as a percent of sales declined to 8.1% from 8.8% in the third quarter last year. Diluted net income per common share for the quarter increased $0.09 or 6% to $1.60 per share from $1.51 per share in 2009. Acquisitions reduced diluted net income per common share by $0.02 per share in the quarter, which was partially offset by favorable currency fluctuation rate changes, which increased diluted net income per common share by $0.01 per share.
Looking at our results by operating segment. Sales for our Paint Stores Group in the third quarter increased 5.4% to $1.286 billion. Improving architectural paint sales to residential repaint contractors and DIY [do-it-yourself] customers and selling price increases more than offset continued weakness in new residential and commercial markets. 
Comparable store sales, that is, sales by stores open more than 12 calendar months, increased 5.1% in the quarter compared to the third quarter last year. Regionally, in the third quarter 2010, our Southeastern division led the sales performance, followed by Midwest division, Southwest division and Eastern division. Sales by all four Paint Store divisions increased in the third quarter compared to last year.
Segment profit for the group decreased $5.1 million or 2.2% to $225.1 million in the quarter. And higher year-over-year raw material costs and selling, general and administrative expenses more than offset selling price increases. 
Operating margin decreased to 17.5% from 18.9% in the third quarter last year. 
During the quarter, Paint Stores Group opened 12 new stores and closed four redundant stores.
Turning to the Consumer Group. Sales in the third quarter increased 3% to $340.4 million, reflecting moderately higher demand in some of the segment's retail, industrial and institutional customers. Segment profit for the Consumer Group increased $3.2 million or 5.7% in the quarter to $59.7 million, due primarily to good expense control and savings from manufacturing site rationalization completed the previous year that were partially offset by raw material cost increases. Segment profit as a percent of external sales increased to 17.5% from 17.1% in the same period last year.
For our Global Finishes Group, sales in U.S. dollars increased 22.6% to $544.5 million in the quarter, due primarily to acquisitions, higher paint sales volume and favorable currency translation rate changes. In the quarter, acquisitions increased Global Finishes Group net sales in U.S. dollars by 15.1%, and favorable currency translation rate changes increased sales in U.S. dollars by 2.5%. 
Third quarter segment profit increased $2.3 million or 7.6% to $31.9 million. Higher paint sales volumes, favorable currency rate changes and good expense control were mostly offset by higher raw material costs and the negative effect of acquisitions. Currency rate changes increased segment profit by $1.4 million, while acquisitions reduced segment profit by $2.8 million. 
Global Finishes Group opened or acquired 20 new branches and closed two branches in the third quarter.
Turning to our balance sheet. Our total debt on September 30, 2010, was $1.066 billion compared to $711 million in the third quarter 2009. Our cash balance at the end of the quarter was $64.9 million compared to $32.8 million at the end of third quarter last year. 
Total borrowings to capitalization were 39.4% at the end of the quarter versus 29.5% at the end of the third quarter 2009. Short-term borrowings decreased $57 million to $354.6 million compared to third quarter last year. And long-term debt to capitalization was 26.3% at the end of the third quarter this year compared to 12.4% last year.
In the third quarter this year, we spent $28.7 million on capital expenditures. Depreciation expense was $34.5 million, and amortization was $8.6 million. Full year 2010, we anticipate capital expenditures for the year will be approximately $100 million to $115 million. Depreciation will be about $140 million, and amortization will be about $35 million. 
That concludes my review of our results for third quarter 2010. So I will turn the call over to Chris Connor, who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for the remainder of the year. Chris?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. From a demand perspective, the third quarter actually started to feel a little bit more normal to us. And we posted solid revenue and volume growth in the quarter, including a 5% co
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. From a demand perspective, the third quarter actually started to feel a little bit more normal to us. And we posted solid revenue and volume growth in the quarter, including a 5% comp store sales gain, even though many segments of our end markets continue to struggle. What did not feel normal is the fact that we failed to generate earnings leverage on this revenue growth. 
Our sales in the third quarter came in about as we had expected. When you back out revenue from the Becker Acroma acquisition, which was completed during the quarter but not included in our guidance, our sales increased 7.3% which was in the dead center of our range of mid- to high-single digits. A little more than half of this sales improvement was from increased volume, the balance coming from a combination of price and favorable mix for the company.
Earnings per share for the quarter, also adjusted for the Becker Acroma acquisition, finished in the middle of our guidance range of $1.55 to $1.70. We knew going into the quarter that earnings improvement would be challenging, even with the solid sales increase and we guided accordingly. Three key factors contributed to our cautious outlook: continued raw material cost pressure, higher SG&A expense and dilution from acquisitions. And let me comment briefly on each of these three issues a little further. 
First, the persistently higher raw material costs we experienced during the first half did not abate in the third quarter. And some commodities, such as titanium dioxide are still rising. We are also continuing to experience higher operating cost result from material supply shortages. Many of the extraordinary actions we've taken during the year to ensure uninterrupted supply of raw materials to our plants and finished goods to our stores continued to impact our P&L. Despite our efforts to help offset these higher input costs, including multiple price increases announced during the year, the normal lag between raw material cost inflation and higher effective pricing has pressured our gross margin in the second and third quarters and most likely will again in the fourth. Implementation of our price increases is progressing as expected, and we remain confident that we will ultimately close the gap on these input costs.
Second, in addition to the impact of lower gross margin in the quarter, operating income was also impacted by higher SG&A expense. And this higher    spending level is also likely to continue for the balance of the year. SG&A expense was up almost $50 million, completed September 1, were dilutive to earnings in the third quarter and again will be for the balance for the year. Although we knew this when we closed these deals, this dilution was not included in our initial earnings guidance provided in January, nor was the Becker acquisition included in our first quarter or second quarter updates to guidance given in July due to the unknown timing of the closing of these acquisitions.
Moving on to some other areas of focus for the company. We continued to manage working capital efficiently and generated significant net operating cash in the quarter. In the first nine months of 2010, we generated $478 million in net operating cash. Working capital for the nine months increased $140 million as the result of higher accounts receivable and inventory to support our sales increase. Working capital as a percent of sales increased to 13.4% from 12.5% last year. Acquisitions added 130 basis points to working capital as a percent of sales.
Our free cash flow, net operating cash less CapEx and dividend, came in at $284 million. We continue to invest the company's cash to expand our controlled distribution platform, complete suitable acquisitions and purchase shares of our stock for treasury. 
Year-to-date, our Paint Stores Group has opened 25 new store locations and consolidated 11 redundant locations. We finished the quarter with 3,368 stores in operation compared to 3,344 this time last year. For the full year, we still expect to open 40 to 50 stores and slow the pace of store closings.
On October 1, we completed the acquisition of Pinturas Cndor, the leading paint and coatings company in Ecuador. The company develops and manufactures products for the architectural, industrial and automotive vehicle refinish markets and sells them through a combination of company-owned paint stores, as well as exclusive dealers in more than 1,800 independent dealers in the country. Sales in 2009 were approximately USD $51 million. 
During the quarter, we also used the company's cash to buy back 1.13 million shares of our common stock on the open market at an average price of $59.39. This brings our year-to-date total to 3.48 million shares. On September 30, we have remaining board authorization to purchase 7.3 million shares.
While it appears the architectural repaint markets in the Americas and global demand for most investor coatings have stabilized or even rebounded somewhat, raw materials remain a challenge for the foreseeable future. Our outlook for the fourth quarter 2010 is for consolidated net sales to increase in the midteens percentage compared to last year's fourth quarter due primarily to acquisitions. We expect fourth quarter diluted net income per common share to be in the range of $0.59 to $0.69 per share compared to $0.58 per share in 2009. For the full year 2010, we expect consolidated net sales to increase in the high single-digit percentage range compared to last year. With annual sales at that level, we are updating our July 22 of 2010 full year guidance for diluted net income per common share to be in the range of $4.12 to $4.22 per share compared to $3.78 per share earned in 2009. 
As a reminder, our full year guidance includes an $0.08 per share charge for higher interest expense in the second quarter, a $0.10 per share charge taken in the first quarter related to the healthcare legislation and $0.07 dilution from two acquisitions completed during the year. Finally, last week, our Board of Directors declared a regular quarterly dividend of $0.36 per share, keeping us on track to achieve our 32nd consecutive year of increased dividends. 
Again, I'd like to thank you for joining us this morning. And now the management team would be happy to take your questions.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from the line of Bob Koort with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from the line of Bob Koort with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Brian Maguire on for Bob. I was just hoping to dig into the raw material cost pressure a little bit more. You mentioned titanium dioxide. I was hoping you could maybe quantify what kind of year-over-year price increases you're seeing. And then may
componenttext: This is Brian Maguire on for Bob. I was just hoping to dig into the raw material cost pressure a little bit more. You mentioned titanium dioxide. I was hoping you could maybe quantify what kind of year-over-year price increases you're seeing. And then maybe you could also talk about what's going on with some of the other raw materials, whether some of the pressure from the first half of the year is abating, or if you're seeing continued pressure there.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. For the first half of the year, most of the inflation we saw on the material basket was acrylic monomers and acrylic latex. And although the supply situation is getting better in the acrylic chain, we're not seeing much relief on the price sid
componenttext: Yes, Brian. For the first half of the year, most of the inflation we saw on the material basket was acrylic monomers and acrylic latex. And although the supply situation is getting better in the acrylic chain, we're not seeing much relief on the price side yet in acrylics. At the same time, as Chris mentioned, titanium dioxide is starting to heat up. We're seeing pressure on TiO2. The pressure for this year is embedded in our outlook for the full year for the raw material basket to be up in the high single digits. Year-to-date, it's probably mid to high, with the highest level of inflation being in the fourth quarter. For next year, we're seeing analyst outlooks across a pretty broad range, with the high probably being in the 40% to 50% inflation range. Most analysts put titanium inflation for 2011 in the range of 20% to 30%, and we think that, that feels about right based on the tightness in the supply right now.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the cadence of losses from acquisitions, you mentioned there was about $2.8 million in this quarter. I was wondering if you might give some indication of how that will track over the next quarter or two, and when you might expect the dilution to end?
componenttext: On the cadence of losses from acquisitions, you mentioned there was about $2.8 million in this quarter. I was wondering if you might give some indication of how that will track over the next quarter or two, and when you might expect the dilution to end?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris mentioned in his comments that for the full year, we expect it to be up $0.07. It was $0.02 in the third quarter. That brought us year-to-date up to $0.05, so it's going to be $0.02 on the fourth quarter. We believe that the first quarter will
componenttext: Yes, Chris mentioned in his comments that for the full year, we expect it to be up $0.07. It was $0.02 in the third quarter. That brought us year-to-date up to $0.05, so it's going to be $0.02 on the fourth quarter. We believe that the first quarter will be dilutive. But after that and starting in the second quarter, we'll start to see accretion.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the $2.8 million expense, does that include rebranding or conversions of any of the acquired companies? Or is that strictly just kind of amortization expense and lower margin or profitability for those businesses?
componenttext: And the $2.8 million expense, does that include rebranding or conversions of any of the acquired companies? Or is that strictly just kind of amortization expense and lower margin or profitability for those businesses?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, those are operating hits and cost of acquisitions again, and there won't be significant expense towards rebranding at this point in time.
componenttext: Yes, those are operating hits and cost of acquisitions again, and there won't be significant expense towards rebranding at this point in time.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Kevin McCarthy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Kevin McCarthy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on raw materials. If I think about the pace of inflation here on a relative basis compared to the selling price increases that you've announced, would 3Q be the quarter of maximum margin compression if we think about the spread there? Or
componenttext: Just a follow-up on raw materials. If I think about the pace of inflation here on a relative basis compared to the selling price increases that you've announced, would 3Q be the quarter of maximum margin compression if we think about the spread there? Or do you anticipate more severity over the next quarter or two?

componenttextpreview: I think if you look at our quarter, last year in the fourth quarter, we were over 37% for the quarter, a stand-alone quarter. I'm sorry, 47%. When we take a look at the this year, we think that the degradation from last year as a percent that'll be the gr
componenttext: I think if you look at our quarter, last year in the fourth quarter, we were over 37% for the quarter, a stand-alone quarter. I'm sorry, 47%. When we take a look at the this year, we think that the degradation from last year as a percent that'll be the greatest difference in this year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow up on pricing. What is the outlook in the Consumer segment, relative to the increases that you've already announced in Paint Stores?
componenttext: And then just a follow up on pricing. What is the outlook in the Consumer segment, relative to the increases that you've already announced in Paint Stores?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've been pretty consistent about sharing with the Street our pricing activities. We announced that in the middle of the third quarter, specifically in August that we took pricing to the market in all of our Architectural businesses, include
componenttext: Yes, I think we've been pretty consistent about sharing with the Street our pricing activities. We announced that in the middle of the third quarter, specifically in August that we took pricing to the market in all of our Architectural businesses, included Consumer Group that you're specifically asking about, Kevin. And as we commented, the implementation in these price increases has gone pretty well, pretty in line with our historic performance and trucking (sic) [tracking] along appropriately. And when we took that pricing in August, we were able to have very good visibility of the impact that we've been hitting during the first half of the year, obviously. But also, the titanium pressure was starting to build at that point in time, so that was the pricing we took to offset Bob's comments that we're seeing the basket of raws for the industry move up into the mid- to high-single digits for this year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Kevin, I should also mention we freely give this guidance that we believe that our gross margin for the full year will be slightly below 45%. So when you look at the 44.8% through the first three quarters, we're going to be slightly below 45%. So you
componenttext: And Kevin, I should also mention we freely give this guidance that we believe that our gross margin for the full year will be slightly below 45%. So when you look at the 44.8% through the first three quarters, we're going to be slightly below 45%. So you can see what we think the gross profit going to come in at in the fourth quarter.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: In TiO2, I guess some competitors or some paint companies can access TiO2 from China, where there seems to be a lot of capacity growth. Whereas everywhere else, there's not much growth. Because you're largely a domestic seller of paints, is that something
componenttext: In TiO2, I guess some competitors or some paint companies can access TiO2 from China, where there seems to be a lot of capacity growth. Whereas everywhere else, there's not much growth. Because you're largely a domestic seller of paints, is that something that you can't really access? or can you? How do you see that?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we absolutely have the ability to access titanium, Jeff, from a variety of different locations around the world. This is a global commodity, with operations now in multiple continents and countries around the world. We're buying titanium from a varie
componenttext: Yes, we absolutely have the ability to access titanium, Jeff, from a variety of different locations around the world. This is a global commodity, with operations now in multiple continents and countries around the world. We're buying titanium from a variety of different sources, including Chinese suppliers as you mentioned. So not a problem.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So over, say, a multiyear period, do you see the supply demand balance in titanium dioxide loosening up or continuing to stay pretty tight?
componenttext: So over, say, a multiyear period, do you see the supply demand balance in titanium dioxide loosening up or continuing to stay pretty tight?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're the wrong guys to be asking that question, right? The titanium producers are the folks that need to answer that for us. We've been fairly consistent in saying that while there certainly is pricing pressure on titanium than it's taking in this
componenttext: Well, we're the wrong guys to be asking that question, right? The titanium producers are the folks that need to answer that for us. We've been fairly consistent in saying that while there certainly is pricing pressure on titanium than it's taking in this market, the availability of titanium is not an issue for the short term or the near-term outlook in terms of gallons that we're going to  need to manufacture. And we would remind all of the listeners on the call that speaking specifically in the United States and to the equal amount -- the world's been through somewhat of a global recession here. We've seen significant falloff in the manufacturing of architectural paint coatings, which is the primary user of these titanium backside raw material. From 800-million-some gallons down to 500 million gallon range, and we just don't think that much capacity came out of the industry. So the long-winded answer of saying that we're comfortable that there's capacity out there. We're not going to have an issue dealing that side of it. It'll be all in the pricing.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Normally, your inventories sequentially go down in the third quarter, but this time they went up by about $65 million. Why is that?
componenttext: Normally, your inventories sequentially go down in the third quarter, but this time they went up by about $65 million. Why is that?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think a part of that is really the raw material piece of the inventory, Jeff. You can start to see those. As Bob mentioned the basket, how large the basket is, is when you compare it to what our growth in the inventory is. You can start to see that raw
componenttext: I think a part of that is really the raw material piece of the inventory, Jeff. You can start to see those. As Bob mentioned the basket, how large the basket is, is when you compare it to what our growth in the inventory is. You can start to see that raw material costs being converted into finished goods.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, organically, did your gallonage grow domestically in the quarter or globally in the quarter?
componenttext: And then lastly, organically, did your gallonage grow domestically in the quarter or globally in the quarter?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It did, Jeff. It grew low-single digits.
componenttext: It did, Jeff. It grew low-single digits.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The recent slowdown that we're seeing in foreclosure activity that is likely to have some negative impact on existing home sales. So do you think that can be a risk to fourth quarter or early for the 2011 volumes?
componenttext: The recent slowdown that we're seeing in foreclosure activity that is likely to have some negative impact on existing home sales. So do you think that can be a risk to fourth quarter or early for the 2011 volumes?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think that the typical drivers of architectural paint demand in the U.S. have been crippled for quite sometime. And certainly, the new construction market declined rapidly years ago. Resale or turnover has traditionally been a driver of coatings volume
componenttext: We think that the typical drivers of architectural paint demand in the U.S. have been crippled for quite sometime. And certainly, the new construction market declined rapidly years ago. Resale or turnover has traditionally been a driver of coatings volume, less so in this environment. So as the challenges in the foreclosure market continue to work themselves out, we think that most of the volume demand in the states will be driven by just cycle paining, amongst homeowners that are staying in their home.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: But earlier in the year, you had mentioned that foreclosure was a growth driver and you had a foreclosure team...
componenttext: But earlier in the year, you had mentioned that foreclosure was a growth driver and you had a foreclosure team...

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that was a miscommunication, P.J. What we've said is that foreclosure activity really doesn't drive volume in our markets. The banks selling properties to investors is not nearly as good for us as an owner-occupant selling to a new owner-occu
componenttext: Yes, I think that was a miscommunication, P.J. What we've said is that foreclosure activity really doesn't drive volume in our markets. The banks selling properties to investors is not nearly as good for us as an owner-occupant selling to a new owner-occupant.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: There is a lot of excitement about this paintless primer introduced by two of your competitors. And do you think that could have some negative impact on your Consumer Group?
componenttext: There is a lot of excitement about this paintless primer introduced by two of your competitors. And do you think that could have some negative impact on your Consumer Group?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. Quality architectural paints and quite a few products in our line also have this capability to act as paint and primer in one. If you're going over previously unpainted surfaces, these competitive products articulate that two coats a
componenttext: No, I don't think so. Quality architectural paints and quite a few products in our line also have this capability to act as paint and primer in one. If you're going over previously unpainted surfaces, these competitive products articulate that two coats are needed. So I think it's an interesting marketing approach. A good-quality paint should be able to handle these types of projects in one or two coats, and we have full basket of these products as well as in our line.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Dennis McGill with Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Dennis McGill with Zelman & Associates.

componenttext: Just to clarify the fourth quarter revenue guidance, Sean, how much should we model for the benefit from acquisitions for the quarter?

componenttextpreview: We think that when you think about midteens, probably just about half of that will be for acquisitions.
componenttext: We think that when you think about midteens, probably just about half of that will be for acquisitions.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: So when you think about it from an organic standpoint, you could actually see an acceleration relative to the third quarter even though comps are a little bit more challenging year-over-year.

componenttext: Yes. If you take a look at the third quarter, our total sales were up 8.8%. Net of acquisitions that was 5.4%. We can see an acceleration from that 5.4%.

componenttext: Yes, all those things.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know there's been a lot of comments out there, most of which I think are probably inaccurate around what happened with some of the share loss at Wal-Mart. Can you just clarify what that announcement means for your business, and also sort of the timing o
componenttext: I know there's been a lot of comments out there, most of which I think are probably inaccurate around what happened with some of the share loss at Wal-Mart. Can you just clarify what that announcement means for your business, and also sort of the timing of when that'll actually start to close here on the revenue side?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the decision that Wal-Mart made was to displace their two branded product offerings, which were our Dutch Boy and another product supplied by Masco, with the Glidden brand; and then move some of their volume of their house brand, which is ColorPlace,
componenttext: Yes, the decision that Wal-Mart made was to displace their two branded product offerings, which were our Dutch Boy and another product supplied by Masco, with the Glidden brand; and then move some of their volume of their house brand, which is ColorPlace, to AkzoNobel and away from some of their current suppliers. In total, we have reported that in terms of revenue loss for us on a full year basis, it would be less than $100 million.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as far as the timing on that, are you starting to see that now with the order shipments? Or is that later?
componenttext: And as far as the timing on that, are you starting to see that now with the order shipments? Or is that later?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: With our fourth quarter guidance at $15 million and about half of that being organic, if there is an impact in the fourth quarter, it's not significant.
componenttext: With our fourth quarter guidance at $15 million and about half of that being organic, if there is an impact in the fourth quarter, it's not significant.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think just from what we're operating under, Dennis, is the expectation that the branding part of this business will move first. And that is, as the paint season unfolds next, you should probably see Wal-Mart's new branding position on shelf. And the pri
componenttext: I think just from what we're operating under, Dennis, is the expectation that the branding part of this business will move first. And that is, as the paint season unfolds next, you should probably see Wal-Mart's new branding position on shelf. And the private label work flowing behind, that won't be as evident to the marketplace. But all of these things should be well underway by the first quarter of next year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one last question, ticking the comments you made about the dilution in the global segment. It is right to assume that the margins there, but excluding the acquisitions, were up 50 or 100 basis points year-over-year?
componenttext: And then just one last question, ticking the comments you made about the dilution in the global segment. It is right to assume that the margins there, but excluding the acquisitions, were up 50 or 100 basis points year-over-year?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you take a look without acquisitions in the third quarter -- no. Actually, I misspoke there. Without the acquisitions, they were not up that much. But for the full year, they're going to be almost twice of what they were last year.
componenttext: Yes. When you take a look without acquisitions in the third quarter -- no. Actually, I misspoke there. Without the acquisitions, they were not up that much. But for the full year, they're going to be almost twice of what they were last year.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from John Roberts with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from John Roberts with Buckingham Research.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of clarifications. One, it sounds like you expect to fully restore margins after freight raw materials stabilize?
componenttext: A couple of clarifications. One, it sounds like you expect to fully restore margins after freight raw materials stabilize?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think when you take a look at the long term, the way we run the company, when the raws go up, we usually see some depression in our gross margin. And it's happening again. But over a course of time, 12 to 18 months, we eventually come back and reco
componenttext: Yes. I think when you take a look at the long term, the way we run the company, when the raws go up, we usually see some depression in our gross margin. And it's happening again. But over a course of time, 12 to 18 months, we eventually come back and recover our gross margin. So last year was the all-time peak at 46%, or could be slightly below 45% this year. We think that eventually, we're going to be back in that 46% range.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, could you comment on the commercial repaint market? There's a lot more square footage out there, obviously, since you've talked about in the past because of all the construction activity over the past several years. It seems like we're having a
componenttext: Secondly, could you comment on the commercial repaint market? There's a lot more square footage out there, obviously, since you've talked about in the past because of all the construction activity over the past several years. It seems like we're having a lag here in getting the repaint activity to pick up in commercial.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's accurate, John. Most of the lift that we're seeing this year, we've commented, come from the residential repaint market. And the commercial repaint market has actually been one of those areas that we're seeing stress in. Two numbers that you l
componenttext: Yes, that's accurate, John. Most of the lift that we're seeing this year, we've commented, come from the residential repaint market. And the commercial repaint market has actually been one of those areas that we're seeing stress in. Two numbers that you look at to help support that would be the vacancy rate at both retail and office; big users of residential repaint products and contractors time, and both of these numbers are running at pretty high rates, historically. So much like we needed to get this kind of glut of housing through the residential side to start to see some lift there. We need to see occupancy rates for overbilled retail space rebound, as well as in office. To that end, very little, if any, new commercial construction activity happening in the United States this year in those spaces. We think this is the first time in about four years that there hasn't been a major retail conflict on our construction somewhere in the United States. So we're going to have to wait a while before that glut goes through. And our guidance for this year was that commercial repaint would be a soft segment for the company, and it's certainly proven to be the case.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is industrial and government repaint activity picking up enough to have any effect here on your overall...
componenttext: Is industrial and government repaint activity picking up enough to have any effect here on your overall...

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. That's certainly better than the commercial repaint and actually quite strong. It was a real help in the quarter. Not only are we seeing some of the impact of the stimulus money in infrastructure projects, but as typical in a cycle like t
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. That's certainly better than the commercial repaint and actually quite strong. It was a real help in the quarter. Not only are we seeing some of the impact of the stimulus money in infrastructure projects, but as typical in a cycle like this, you can only hold off on maintaining these kinds of assets for so long and then you need to get back on them. So our Protective and marine Coatings business, both domestically as well as around the world, is actually performing quite nicely right now.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Douglas Chudy with KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Douglas Chudy with KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: You noted some temporary elevation in SG&A. But taking a longer-term view, do you sense that as your volumes improve you can ratchet that SG&A as a percentage of sales back down to, say, that 32%, 33% level you saw in 2006, 2007?
componenttext: You noted some temporary elevation in SG&A. But taking a longer-term view, do you sense that as your volumes improve you can ratchet that SG&A as a percentage of sales back down to, say, that 32%, 33% level you saw in 2006, 2007?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that as a percent of sales, for sure, that over the course of time, you're going to see us ratchet that SG&A down as a percent of sales. I think though that we saw the SG&A improvement in the first six months of the year versus the last tax m
componenttext: Yes, I think that as a percent of sales, for sure, that over the course of time, you're going to see us ratchet that SG&A down as a percent of sales. I think though that we saw the SG&A improvement in the first six months of the year versus the last tax month of the year. I think you're starting to see that our SG&A from the closed stores and all the activities we've done. We've now really getting close to a more normalized rate. As we get more volume, then I think you're going to start seeing that SG&A as a percent of sales continue to go down.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just to a follow-up on the Wal-Mart business. Do you have any concerns that some of your Wal-Mart business could be at risk here?
componenttext: And then secondly, just to a follow-up on the Wal-Mart business. Do you have any concerns that some of your Wal-Mart business could be at risk here?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Business is always at risk at all these third-party retailers that we business with. Having said that, the programs are performing well. These are strong brands that are at Wal-Mart, Minwax, Thompson's, Krylon. And our expectations are going forward that,
componenttext: Business is always at risk at all these third-party retailers that we business with. Having said that, the programs are performing well. These are strong brands that are at Wal-Mart, Minwax, Thompson's, Krylon. And our expectations are going forward that, that won't be an issue for us, but time will tell.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, can you comment on the sequential demand trends? I mean, it sounded that you were a little bit more optimistic. I mean, have you seen any sort of a pickup here in the early parts of the fourth quarter versus what you were seeing dur
componenttext: And then just finally, can you comment on the sequential demand trends? I mean, it sounded that you were a little bit more optimistic. I mean, have you seen any sort of a pickup here in the early parts of the fourth quarter versus what you were seeing during the third quarter?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Again, I think the residential repaint component of the business continue to show some strength, that Sean clarified the kind of fourth quarter sales guidance. With acquisitions out, we're looking in kind of that mid to upper single-digit range here.
componenttext: No. Again, I think the residential repaint component of the business continue to show some strength, that Sean clarified the kind of fourth quarter sales guidance. With acquisitions out, we're looking in kind of that mid to upper single-digit range here. So all that's an indication that we're seeing a little better performance for the company. I think that clearly, there's market share gains being generated here. But also, we're seeing a little better health in our end markets.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Dmitry Silversteyn with Longbow Research.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Dmitry Silversteyn with Longbow Research.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've had a pretty decent volume growth in the global market. I mean, it's global and industrial. So was the growth more on the architectural side and Latin America? Or was the growth more on half the market, the automotive and maintenance and marine and
componenttext: You've had a pretty decent volume growth in the global market. I mean, it's global and industrial. So was the growth more on the architectural side and Latin America? Or was the growth more on half the market, the automotive and maintenance and marine and global coatings?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, the architectural volume for the quarter was a little bit higher than the automotive or the industrial. But the automotive and industrial were fairly strong for us.
componenttext: Actually, the architectural volume for the quarter was a little bit higher than the automotive or the industrial. But the automotive and industrial were fairly strong for us.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you actually did have mid to high single-digit growth, it sounds like, in architectural paint, Latin America.
componenttext: So you actually did have mid to high single-digit growth, it sounds like, in architectural paint, Latin America.

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttextpreview: And did that come largely as a function of adding new stores? Or did you also disclose a same-store sales for the global business, like you do for domestic?
componenttext: And did that come largely as a function of adding new stores? Or did you also disclose a same-store sales for the global business, like you do for domestic?

componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't do comp store sales for our global business, probably something we should think about doing going forward, Dmitry. A fair question. I would just say that just a better architectural health in the key architectural segments, Brazil, Mexico, Argent
componenttext: We don't do comp store sales for our global business, probably something we should think about doing going forward, Dmitry. A fair question. I would just say that just a better architectural health in the key architectural segments, Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Chile really drive Latin America for us. So through our stores, our dealer network, our home centers, all doing nicely right now.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then not to so much concentrate on the loss of the business at Wal-Mart, but kind of what that loss represents beyond the P&L impact? And how do you view your brands outside of Sherwin-Williams? Obviously, you have a very good and very strong brand in
componenttext: And then not to so much concentrate on the loss of the business at Wal-Mart, but kind of what that loss represents beyond the P&L impact? And how do you view your brands outside of Sherwin-Williams? Obviously, you have a very good and very strong brand in Minwax and Thomson's Seal-This (sic) [WaterSeal], and just about every distribution channel you can think of. Krylon is a good brand. But is there much behind that? Or are you going to have to address at some point your stable of brands and see how viable some of these are longer term, particularly Dutch Boy but also beyond Dutch Boy?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we should be thinking about that all the time, Dmitry, in working to strengthen the brands that we have in the company. We would point out that, that the third largest home centers chain in the United States, Menards, is a terrific partner for our D
componenttext: Well, we should be thinking about that all the time, Dmitry, in working to strengthen the brands that we have in the company. We would point out that, that the third largest home centers chain in the United States, Menards, is a terrific partner for our Dutch Boy brand. And there are dozens of other regional home centers, discount, hardware chains across the United States that is helping us market that brand. So we're committed to the staple of brands we have. There's no movement of port [ph] because of this one decision by Wal-Mart to change any kind of channel strategy or support for the brands we have inside the company.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Trey Grooms with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Trey Grooms with Stephens.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions back just on the raw materials. Just briefly, can you remind us how much of your paying costs are associated with TiO2?
componenttext: A couple of questions back just on the raw materials. Just briefly, can you remind us how much of your paying costs are associated with TiO2?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's in the low 20%. TiO2 represents the 21%, 22% of the cost of our total raw material basket.
componenttext: Yes, it's in the low 20%. TiO2 represents the 21%, 22% of the cost of our total raw material basket.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if I understood right, you're kind of thinking, or at least you think it's the most realistic expectation, is that those costs might be up 20% to 30% next year?
componenttext: So if I understood right, you're kind of thinking, or at least you think it's the most realistic expectation, is that those costs might be up 20% to 30% next year?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's what it looks like now.
componenttext: That's what it looks like now.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so that would imply, I think, like 4% to 6% price increase needed to help offset that particular increase in costs?
componenttext: And so that would imply, I think, like 4% to 6% price increase needed to help offset that particular increase in costs?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that would be the math to get to the raw material cost input. But the pricing that we would need would be about half of that, as raws as a basket of goods account for about half of the average selling price of a gallon of architectural paint.
componenttext: Well, that would be the math to get to the raw material cost input. But the pricing that we would need would be about half of that, as raws as a basket of goods account for about half of the average selling price of a gallon of architectural paint.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then also, your thoughts kind of on acrylic prices. I know you said that supply looks like it's getting better, but the prices continue to be high. Do you think that, that's going to kind of continue? Or do you think at some point, we'll start to see
componenttext: And then also, your thoughts kind of on acrylic prices. I know you said that supply looks like it's getting better, but the prices continue to be high. Do you think that, that's going to kind of continue? Or do you think at some point, we'll start to see those move down again?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's obviously a good question, and one that we're all paying attention to. Our practice, Trey, has been at that first quarter call to give you guidance on what we're seeing for the industry for the year. It's just a little early for us to
componenttext: Yes, I think that's obviously a good question, and one that we're all paying attention to. Our practice, Trey, has been at that first quarter call to give you guidance on what we're seeing for the industry for the year. It's just a little early for us to start going down the whole basket of raw materials here. There's so much noise around titanium, and there's a lot of preps on that now that's why Bob wanted to comment on that kind of ranges that we're seeing out there. It's just too early to make this call and the others. Supply is easing, as Bob mentioned. And we're off of the force majeure and some of the struggles we've had earlier in the year. We need to let that settle in a little bit, get through our year-end negotiations with these folks. And we'll give you as much visibility and guidance that we possibly can in the first quarter.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, the titanium dioxide, the 20% to 30%,  and maybe I'm missing something, but that seems to be a tremendous amount of inflation in a very important raw material. And I guess my question is, is that actually where you think it ends up in 2011?
componenttext: First of all, the titanium dioxide, the 20% to 30%,  and maybe I'm missing something, but that seems to be a tremendous amount of inflation in a very important raw material. And I guess my question is, is that actually where you think it ends up in 2011? And secondly, when you put through your August price increase, you had commented that, that reflected what you had seen in inputs. I'm assuming that titanium dioxide has worsened materially since that pricing decision was made. Can you just give a little bit of little color on those two items?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Bob's comments were relative to some of the chemical analyst reports that we're reading, Eric, not so much hard negotiation at the table. And I looked this up with some of the costs in the industry for calendar year 2011, so that's just an early look
componenttext: Yes. Bob's comments were relative to some of the chemical analyst reports that we're reading, Eric, not so much hard negotiation at the table. And I looked this up with some of the costs in the industry for calendar year 2011, so that's just an early look to kind of the pressure. You're correct in your assessment. This is remarkable inflation in price for product line that has and typically gone through its ups and downs. We're just going to have to wait, all the time go by here until that kind of settles in and we see what the number comes in at. We're not giving guidance on this call for 2011, cost increase for the industry, and we absolutely will hold true to our commitment to give that to you in the first quarter.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the second half of my question, that was the pricing in August. I don't know if you can give any color that the input cost environment has changed since that pricing decision was made.
componenttext: In terms of the second half of my question, that was the pricing in August. I don't know if you can give any color that the input cost environment has changed since that pricing decision was made.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that what you categorized earlier about the TiO2 situation worsening before we went out with that price increase and in terms of the percentage we needed, I would say that the TiO2 pricing has become more dire than what we have there at t
componenttext: Yes, I would say that what you categorized earlier about the TiO2 situation worsening before we went out with that price increase and in terms of the percentage we needed, I would say that the TiO2 pricing has become more dire than what we have there at that time.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, on the progress with that August increase, Chris, you said it's kind of gone through on a normal basis or similar to what's happened historically. Can you give any further color about the markets, what happens to price increases?
componenttext: And then secondly, on the progress with that August increase, Chris, you said it's kind of gone through on a normal basis or similar to what's happened historically. Can you give any further color about the markets, what happens to price increases?

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that when you take a look at it, it's always difficult. But if take a look at on the store side, and the consumer side is just as difficult as  always. But I would tell you, when we look at the effectiveness of that August 16 plus having just
componenttext: Yes, I think that when you take a look at it, it's always difficult. But if take a look at on the store side, and the consumer side is just as difficult as  always. But I would tell you, when we look at the effectiveness of that August 16 plus having just a little bit of a mix, again positive mix that we've had in the past; now it's only been about six weeks, Eric, but when we take a look at it, we think that price increase probably has gone in just as well as any that we've put it in the last 10 years.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, on the acquisition dilution and the transition to accretion, which sounds like begins in 2Q of next year, can you give us any sense of what the magnitude of that swing is? And then also explain what happens within the business to make it
componenttext: And then lastly, on the acquisition dilution and the transition to accretion, which sounds like begins in 2Q of next year, can you give us any sense of what the magnitude of that swing is? And then also explain what happens within the business to make it go from diluted earnings to accretive.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Probably, if I could just refer you -- later this week, we're going to be putting out our Q and our financials and our footnote. And if you look at Footnote 14, which basically does a pro forma, and what it shows you, and I'll really share with you;
componenttext: Yes, Probably, if I could just refer you -- later this week, we're going to be putting out our Q and our financials and our footnote. And if you look at Footnote 14, which basically does a pro forma, and what it shows you, and I'll really share with you; 2009, if we would've owned Becker as well as Sayerlack from the beginning of '09, a pro forma third quarter would have been at $1.52 and for the first nine months would have been $3.19. And as you know, last year, we earned $1.51, so they would have been accretive by $0.01 and $0.02 for the first nine months. And I think we've talked about that it was lower than for $1-for-$1 for sales for that reason. But when we think about next year, number one, the first thing that's going to cause accretion is that's going against the closing costs. And number two, we think that some of the steps that we're going to take when managing this businesses will be higher than what they were earning in prior years. So I think you can see that you earned $0.01 in the third quarter and $0.02 for the first nine months. We expect to have more than that in a run rate, maybe not because of just the beginning of the changes we're making. But by 2012, we'll start to see more. But I think we'll have more than what they've earned in 2009.

componenttext: Yes, I think when you take a look at the working capital as a percent of sales with these two acquisitions, if you combine them, we're going to be around 30% of sales, which is almost 3x as high as we run the company. But when we segregate our company, we're a little higher outside of the United States because of scale and so forth. But when we look at this, we expect over the next few year we're going to be able to make dramatic improvements in there. The inventory of $859 million, the inventory was $74 million from the acquisition. So when you take a look at that, the remainder was up about 7.2%, 8%. So when you take a look at -- that's again in the high end of the range, as Bob talked about with the raw materials. But you make a great point that 30% working capital, percent of sales, we're going to begin working on that next year.

componenttext: Yes, we're blessed with a customer base, with the professional that has the ability to pass pricing onto their customers, as we have commented frequently on this call. The cost of material is anywhere between 10% to 20% of the cost of the paint jobs, so they're able to mitigate it The likelihood, if some of the chemical analysts are correct, that titanium's up in the 20% to 30% range, we would expect to see the industry go through another round of pricing in calendar 2011. And we'll just have to be prepared to respond to that.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a handful of cities and counties that brought suit in California. And recently, the State Supreme Court ruled on one of our motions and determined that it is permissible for these cities and counties to retain contingency fee counsel to aid i
componenttext: Yes, there's a handful of cities and counties that brought suit in California. And recently, the State Supreme Court ruled on one of our motions and determined that it is permissible for these cities and counties to retain contingency fee counsel to aid in these suits, but that the governmental agencies must retain control over the suit. So that is essentially now sending the matter back to the trial court for further proceeding. We anticipate that, that we still need to complete discovery in those suit, and there's other motion practice issues to resolve there. And then in addition to that, there are a couple of personal injury suits that we face in Mississippi. One being a single point of suit, which was tried to a jury last year, and the jury returned a verdict for the plaintiff. The company has filed a notice of appeal with the Mississippi Supreme Court, and we've now begun briefing. We filed our opening brief this past summer, and the plaintiff filed their brief shortly after that. No hearing date's been set yet, and a decision is not expected until at least mid-2011 on the outcome of that appeal.

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

headline: Sherwin-Williams Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. A couple of things. Of our 3,350 approximate stores, we own right around 260 of them. And so that means that we have many leases, and we try to get a five-year term and four, five-year options with the planned bumps. What's going to happen -- and a l
componenttext: Yes. A couple of things. Of our 3,350 approximate stores, we own right around 260 of them. And so that means that we have many leases, and we try to get a five-year term and four, five-year options with the planned bumps. What's going to happen -- and a lot times will people ask us about our leverage, we always talk about our debt to EBITDA being right around 1%, but really 1.7% if you think about the net present value of those leases. So we've always continued to really point that out. What you're going to see is our level is going to go about 1.7% because what we're going to have to do is put that asset on our books, and we're going to have to put the debt on the books. We're not going to have any problems with our covenants. We looked at our covenants, and I know other companies are taking a look at this and saying that this trigger a covenant issue for them with the banks. We don't have that. The real question will be how much we're to have, on an ongoing basis, change the fair market value of those leases. And that'll be pretty interesting, because we have 20 years control. With the change of interest rate, we might have that going in and out. And unfortunately, I think it really doesn't change the aspect of our company or so forth. We're going to see more volatility on our balance sheet because of this size of asset being changing on an ongoing basis for fair market value. But what we're going to try to do is keep this out of our operating division so that there's still focus on selling paint, which is how we really make paint money.

componenttext: I think the acrylic inventory position in the industry is phenomenally better today than it was two or three quarters ago.
